story:
Handy Gym brings the most innovative inertial technology to the world of fitness! Presented in the form of a compact accessory of a two-pound, contact accesory, Handy Gym contains two inertial discs capable of converting its turn in strength of resistance. It comes with the accessories necessary to make it portable - from your home to the outdoors, you can now workout at any time! It also comes with a wide variety of gripping elements that allow you to perform up to 200 different exercises and work any muscle group you want.

 

 

 

This project is promoted by Jellop, the ad tech power behind the best Kickstarters with 750+ successful Kickstarter projects with over $330MM raised between them.

 

 

 

 

What People Are Saying

While we’re reserving exclusive early access to Handy Gym for you, as our Kickstarter backer, we’re proud to say that we have already conducted a closed market test of the product and we’ve made quite a few athletes and fitness enthusiasts very happy.

MICATON: Who We Are and Where We Stand

We are a team of fitness enthusiasts and serial entrepreneurs who believe in creating smarter devices for smarter and more effective fitness and training experiences. We also wanted to create a device that could be equally used for physical rehabilitation. After all, our CEO, Manuel Montes, who has been dealing with Parkinson’s for 11 years, was the first in our team who tried to create a device to train his mobility at home and we just knew we had to had to get together and develop a device that could be used by anyone, anywhere, at any time.

Three Kickstarter Success Stories

Handy Gym is our fourth Kickstarter campaign, actually. After three successful campaigns in the field of hand tools as Micaton Ergonomics (Magnet Driver DDN, Magnet Driver Space Rocket and Micaton Magnetic Screw Holder were our creations), we are now committed to developing a new product for the fitness world, which we want to make better through our innovative solutions such as Handy Gym.

story:
The Adventure

Beginning August 1st, I’m beginning on a quest to cultivate a robust, diverse, and well-travled microbiome. In other words, I am going to ferment myself.

This means that

  1. Eat live fermented food everyday.  Preferably a bit at each meal.
  2. Learn as much as I can about what contributes to a healthy microbiome and do those things: ie. Dig in the dirt, eat prebiotics (fibrous raw vegetables), and play with lots of animals.
  3. Visit every continent in order to ingest the microorganisms, connect with the people, and learn about the world’s fermentation traditions.

The Rationale

The reasons that I am doing this are:

1. Well first, I admit. I love fermentation. I first was introduced to the idea at workshop that Sandor Katz did at Bastyr University, and I was totally enchanted by the idea that by chopping up some vegetables and adding salt, that you can create a whole living ecosystem. I just find this incredible. Since then, I’ve turned many a jar into a bubbling community of microbes. 

2. I’m 27 and have grand ambitions to settle down and have a family and a farm and babies running everywhere so when that happens, I’m certainly not going to be traveling aound the world fermenting myself so I might as well do it now.

3. And lastly, I’m truly curious about what will happen. How will the microbes change me? Is it true how they say that the microcosm is a reflection of the macrocosm? By changing my insides, will I really change the world. What will happen physically, what will happen mentally, psychologically, spiritually? 

The Plan (In Slightly More Detail)

For the month of August, I will establish a base line by living in the town where I grew up, working on an organic farm, walking a silly labrador named Gertrude, and eating lots of fermented food. I also will do a microbiome analysis through American Gut, a project that is working to map the human microbiome. 

Then, in September, I will take off. Due to previous gypsy tendencies, I have quite a few contacts around the world and am working on setting up an itinerary that begins in Brussels and then takes me to Austria, Portugal, Kenya, Tanzania, Thailand, Japan, the Northwest Territories of Australia, New Zealand, Hawaii, Argentina, Costa Rica, Mexico, and then back to the U.S. I will stay with families and document home fermentation traditions.

I will travel until Christmas 2013 and then return to Michigan, do another microbiome analysis, and let all the fermenting action age for a few months while I write a book. 

My travels and the food traditions that I encounter will be documented on my blog, The Hearth Project, as well as in the book.

 

How You Can Help

I’m looking to raise $20,000 to cover the costs of travel, recording equipment, and to begin the book.  

If you're unable to contribute financially, there are other ways that you can help. 

1. Tell your friends about this adventure. Post, twitter, write, phone, whatever it takes. Please help me get the word out.

2. I'm still looking for contacts especially in Africa and Asia. If you or anyone you know is a fermentation enthusiast in those regions, please e-mail me at rebeccasornson@gmail.com

3. I am open to traveling companions! If you want to accompany me on a leg of this journey, send me an e-mail and let's talk! rebeccasornson@gmail.com

If I don't succeed in reaching my goal, I will still go forward with the project. I may have to adapt my itinerary slightly, but I am committed to self fermentation!

So, in conclusion, if you’d like to support this dream in any way please do.

My biggest hope is that this adventure is inspiring...to you and to the world. Thanks so much for your help!

story:
Breast Cancer Fundraiser Benefit for Dianne LeVasseur

 

My mother has always been the Heartbeat of our family.  My parents worked hard full time all of their lives to raise my two brothers and I.  During those years, my mother is the one who ran the entire house, getting us all to our activities, doctors and making sure dinner was on the table. After spending all of her life caring for others and making sure all their needs were met, she now, is the one in need.  She was diagnosed with Breast Cancer 10 years ago and has undergone a battery of tests and procedures.  Recently, her cancer metastisized to her lung, tailbone and liver and she was upgraded to Stage 4.

As the saying goes, "when it rains, it pours."  Two years ago, in the midst of my mother's battle, my father suffered a fall that left him with a broken rib and a punctured lung.  While being treated, it was discovered that he had prostate cancer as well as an aneurism.  He underwent surgery, but his place of employment of 38 years was unable to hold his position as he endured a long recovery from his fall and subsequent cancer and brain surgeries.  

Now, between the loss of employment and my mother's illness progression, my parents are suffering from the financial strain.  They have always been such hard workers and have never asked or been given any kind of assistance.  In a difficult heart to heart recently, my mother told me that instead of having a funeral she would rather see old friends and family in person.  So, my family is planning a benefit for my mother to not only help raise funds for her treatments, but as a reunion as well.  We are trying to rally as many raffles as possible to help raise money and we are asking a $10.00 ticket price. We are hoping that between any donated raffles as well as the ticket price, some of the financial strain may be lifted so that my mother can focus on her care and enjoying her family and grandchildren as long as possible.

Please consider donating to these wonderful, hardworking people that have stumbled on a hard time at the twilight of their lives.  When they should be relaxing and enjoying their grandchildren, they are worrying about things like, how will they pay the heat bill as well as the cancer medication.  Thank you so much for your consideration of helping my mother. If you knew her, I am certain you would understand what a wonderful loving woman she is and know that your funds are going to a wonderful cause to sustain the life of a beloved Grandmother, mother and wife. 

Thank you so much for reading our story and for your support!

 

The Benefit party is 3/9/13

story:
Maria Isabel needs to go back to Michigan for surgery!!

Unfortunately, her retinas are detaching again after the second set of surgeries she had last year. Apparently a problem with the eye mechanism is causing this problem, and if is not fixed on a timely manner, she could become completely blind! She's only 1 1/2 years, and have suffered 12 surgeries; 11 of them before reaching her 1rst year!!

With your help you can send her, her mom and grandma back to Michigan to have this -hopefully- last surgery so she can see our smiling faces!!

No retinal surgeons in Puerto Rico wants to perform a surgery on her or at least attempt any kind of treatment.

Please, help us with whatever you can!! $1.00 is good if the thousands of friends we all have can give one... If we reach our goal, we can help another baby that has to go back for the same surgery!

Thanks!!!

Note #1: Please read the Primera Hora article and watch the Telemundo news video here. If you don’t understand what it says, don’t worry. Within couple days I'll be posting the translation... and please, return as many times you wish and share this... we need to go there before the year is over!!

 

For a more detailed description you can visit old campaign: http://igg.me/p/206669/x/1046090

Spanish version:

Maria Isabel necesita regresar a Michigan para cirugia!!

Desafortunadamente, sus retinas se están desprendiendo nuevamente después de la segunda sesión de cirugías que tuvo el pasado año. Aparentemente, un problema con el mecanismo del ojo esta causando este desprendimiento, y si no es reparado a tiempo, podría quedar completamente ciega! Ella solo tiene 1 ½ años de edad y ha tenido 12 cirugias, 11 de ellas antes de alcanzar su primer año!!

Con tu ayuda puedes enviarla junto a su mama y su abuela de regreso a Michigan para tener esta, esperemos que asi sea- ultima cirugía, de manera que pueda ver nuestros sonrientes rostros!

Ningun cirujano retinólogo en Puerto Rico quiere realizarle una cirugía o al menos practicarle algún tipo de tratamiento.

Por favor, ayudenos con lo que pueda! $1.00 es bueno si los miles de amigos que todos tenemos pueden dar uno… Si alcanzamos nuestra meta, podemos ayudar a otro bebe que tiene que ir al mismo hospital para la misma operación.

Gracias!!

Nota #1: Por favor, lea el articulo en Primera Hora y vea el video de las noticias de Telemundo. En caso de no entender, no se preocupe. Dentro de pocos días estare posteando la traducción… y por favor, regrese tantas veces desee y comparta esta información… necesitamos regresar antes de que termine el año!!

story:
Update: I am sad and heartbroken to report that Blake lost his battle this morning, 1/12/13. The proceeds of this campaign will still go to Blake’s family to be used towards a scholarship in Blake's name. Thank you to all who have contibuted so far. RIP Blake, you fought a courageous battle.

 

Blake Cognata, 17, from Fairport, NY is battling a rare form of cancer. He was diagnosed Feb. 1 with Ewing’s sarcoma, a form of cancer that attacks the bones.

With just one treatment remaining on his original chemotherapy regimen, Cognata began to feel pain in his shoulder in October. Doctors found the disease had spread dramatically through his body.

I personally do not know Blake, but I do know his Mom and she is one of the sweetest, most loving people I have ever met. She does everything for her children and I would just like to help her and Blake in this difficult time in any way I can. 

All proceeds from this campaign will go to Blake and his family to help with medical expenses.

story:
We are the family of Norma Jean, a 69 year old monarch of her family. Norma was diagnosed on April 5, 2012 with stage 4 Lung Cancer that was suspected to have mestatisized. At that time she was assigned an Oncologist by the hospital who we thought was a very nice person. At the time I took her for an office visit with this oncologist she basically told us to prepare for the worst and then proceeded to tell us that we would need cash payments everytime we came to her office.
 
Well I was particularly frustrated with the small room with no tv and no interaction where Norma was suppose to recieve pallative care. Norma was beat down from the news so I got busy on the internet. I researched "The Cancer Center of America" beacuse the commercials were abundant and I was ready to make the voyage to Philly! BUT they didn't take her insurance.
 
After many let downs I looked in our own back yard...Johns Hopkins Sydney Kimmel Cancer Center! I immediately called and got her registered and didn't even tell her until I confirmed her intake appointment. From day one of going to JH her treatment was prioritized, test were immediate and her cancer was downgraded to Stage 3b, no spread.
 
She embarked on an 8week treatment cycle in a place filled with life and smiles and doctors we could call at anytime. Needless to say this helped in a BIG way to have this support. Now that her treatment is over we've been told the tumor is shrinking and her breathing has improved as well as her outlook on life. She lives for the day and we want to make her days stress free and beautiful which is why we are here...
 

What We Need & What You Get


In light of the news we've tapped our our bank accounts and are not looking to be reimbursed but we need to prepare for future cost that we don't have the finances for because we threw the kitchen sink at getting the treatment done daily for 8 weeks. 

 

The needs are $8300:

  • $3500 toward copays
  • $1800 in her household expenses that are behind
  • $3000 toward funeral pre-arrangement cost (this is a sad reality for us but we stretch the days)

And money towards $1700:

  • Cases of Ensure
  • Fruits and Produce from the Farmers Market
  • Food (Currently "SNAP" only provides her with $79/month)
  • Gas for future appointments
  • Parking vouchers for the JHU Cancer Center
  • A new bed & Pillows for comfort

We will donate 5% to the American Cancer Society. And if we raise "Above & Beyond" the amount it will be used to move Norma Jean to a new apartment complex closer to her family so she can also keep her dog "Bruno" (a Chi-Poo) because her leasing office says they've changed rules and don't allow dogs which is another stresser for her.

The Impact

The impact is BIGGER than you could imagine, this will help releive a ton of stress and let the healing continue! I have not told her about this but have linked this campaign to her bank account and will record a video of us telling her the results of what has been done with this campaign. Norma Jean is a very hard working humble person, we love her, she's our rock.

Other Ways You Can Help

Twitter about it, Facebook it, Share it! Thank you so much.

story:
Making a Difference

My daughter Abby is two years old and has Down syndrome.

  • Abby doesn't have any siblings to run around with and is an only child. She has also been consistently behind her peers in development and even though she is a fun loving, happy toddler, she tends to be very timid about trying new activities. A therapy dog would have a huge impact on her daily life! Part of the duties the dog would perform includes motivating her to practice walking (at two she is not yet walking but very close) and would require regular exercise. Exercise for Abby is also very important because she has been hovering around the 100th percentile for weight since birth and has low muscle tone and a slower metabolism due to her Down syndrome.
  • The dog will also help her navigate her world, will be attuned to her emotional state and will help her calm down if over stimulated or frustrated. The dog can help with stranger intervention to keep her safe and also be there with her during transitions throughout her day.
  • Abby already exhibits a great love for animals and is very gentle when petting them. Having a dog not only trained to meet her needs but also is a dependable, loyal companion will have a profound impact on Abby’s life. I firmly believe that a therapy will not only instill greater self-confidence but also be the motivation she needs to continue to meet her goals and objectives.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The cost of a trained therapy dog is broken down as follows:
  • $35 enrollment
  • $350 startup fee
  • $800 Dog Fee
  • $70 a month for the training of the dog with a 12 month minimum.
  • If our goal isn’t reached on indigogo in the specified time, we are going to continue to fundraise locally until our goal is met.
  • We are excited to offer a personalized photo of Abby with her therapy dog for $25 contributions. Training starts in June so I promise pictures will be in      the mail shortly thereafter. For larger contributions, we are going to have commemorative ornaments made of Abby and her dog.

Organizations Making An Impact

  • Therapy dogs are placed with adults and children who have a physical, cognitive, or emotional need that can be helped with a loving pet or companion. These needs might include depression, loneliness or anxiety. Emotional Support Animals often provide a reason to get up in the morning, motivation to exercise, and they give there human partners someone to care for.
  • We are working with a non-profit organization called Sunstone Service Dogs and their website is: http://www.oregonassistancedogs.org/index

Other Ways You Can Help

  • I understand that financial times are still tough and have been for my family as well. Please, even if you can't contribute personally but feel like it is a worthy cause, share our information with others. Even if people just contributed a dollar, every bit counts and adds up!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Making a Difference
My daughter Abby is two years old and has Down syndrome.

Abby doesn't have any siblings to run around with and is an only child. She has also been consistently behind her peers in development and even though she is a fun loving, happy toddler, she tends to be very timid about trying new activities. A therapy dog would have a huge impact on her daily life! Part of the duties the dog would perform includes motivating her to practice walking (at two she is not yet walking but very close) and would require regular exercise. Exercise for Abby is also very important because she has been hovering around the 100th percentile for weight since birth and has low muscle tone and a slower metabolism due to her Down syndrome.

The dog will also help her navigate her world, will be attuned to her emotional state and will help her calm down if over stimulated or frustrated. The dog can help with stranger intervention to keep her safe and also be there with her during transitions throughout her day.
Abby already exhibits a great love for animals and is very gentle when petting them. Having a dog not only trained to meet her needs but also is a dependable, loyal companion will have a profound impact on Abby’s life. I firmly believe that a therapy will not only instill greater self-confidence but also be the motivation she needs to continue to meet her goals and objectives.

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of a trained therapy dog is broken down as follows:
$35 enrollment
$350 startup fee
$800 Dog Fee
$70 a month for the training of the dog with a 12 month minimum.
If our goal isn’t reached on indigogo in the specified time, we are going to continue to fundraise locally until our goal is met.


We are excited to offer a personalized photo of Abby with her therapy dog for $25 contributions. Training starts in June so I promise pictures will be in      the mail shortly thereafter. For larger contributions, we are going to have commemorative ornaments made of Abby and her dog.

Organizations Making An Impact

Therapy dogs are placed with adults and children who have a physical, cognitive, or emotional need that can be helped with a loving pet or companion. These needs might include depression, loneliness or anxiety. Emotional Support Animals often provide a reason to get up in the morning, motivation to exercise, and they give there human partners someone to care for.


We are working with a non-profit organization called Sunstone Service Dogs and their website is: http://www.oregonassistancedogs.org/index




Other Ways You Can Help


I understand that financial times are still tough and have been for my family as well. Please, even if you can't contribute personally but feel like it is a worthy cause, share our information with others. Even if people just contributed a dollar, every bit counts and adds up!
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Buy It Today on the Indiegogo Marketplace!

 

 

VITASTIQ IS NOW ISO 9001 CERTIFIED!               

Our mother-company, Vitastiq d.o.o., has been granted the certificate by TUV NORD CERT, a third-party auditor, confirming that Vitastiq d.o.o. 'applies a management system in line with the ISO 9001 : 2015 standard in the following areas: design, manufacturing and sales.'

Track your vitamin and mineral trend 

Vitastiq helps indicate the general trend of essential nutrients in your body.

 

An innovative device that tracks your nutrient levels using a smartphone is a
perfect addition to your fit lifestyle and smart dieting habits.

WHAT’S NEW?

Unlike the 1st edition, Vitastiq 2 is wireless. Thanks to Bluetooth technology (BLE 4.0), this gadget has an improved compatibility with smartphones and tablets. It’s made of titanium, a more durable and lighter material.


Advantages of Vitastiq 2:
 

     

      What do you get with Vitastiq:

      • Nutrient readings anytime, anywhere
      • Detailed instructions for quick and easy use
      • Information about nutrients and their natural sources
      • In-app video tutorials
      • Non-invasive, painless method
      • Bluetooth connection for an instant feedback
      • Sophisticated, light gadget made of titanium
      • User-friendly app

      Vitastiq features

      The Vitastiq app saves your previous readings and offers information about nutrients and their natural sources. Vitastiq informs the user about the relationship between their body and a particular vitamin or mineral. With regular use, you will be able to track your general nutrient trend.

       

      Download the FREE Vitastiq app NOW and browse through:

       

      Compatibility
      ​      Android (smartphones and tablets) OS 4.3 or newer
      iOS (iPhone and iPad) OS 9.0 or newer
      *only devices supporting Bluetooth 4.0 or newer (BLE 4.0) can connect to Vitastiq2 and VitastiqFamily

      How to use?

      1.  Launch Vitastiq app.

      2. You can set up your own profile and add more profiles for your family and friends.

      3. Select a template or make your own, and start using Vitastiq. 

      4. Read the instructions and watch video tutorials. All in one app!

       

      Locating a measuring point


      • Find the exact point within 3-5 mm area from the measuring point, as shown above.
      • Slightly and carefully move the tip of the pen within the acupuncture point to find the highest value. Your highest value is the right value.
      • For best results, dampen the tip of the pen using a wet cotton pad before calibrating and before touching each measuring point.

      In-app tutorials will make it easy to use the product and explore all the features. Download the free Vitastiq app to browse the content or visit our website for support. 

        Our success story

        Our first Indiegogo campaign, launched towards the end of 2014, exceeded our original funding goal 5x over. We delivered perks to all our backers on time, and soon after we became a part of the Indiegogo InDemand feature. Vitastiq products were shipped to users in over 90 countries.

        Check out our first campaign!

         

        • Vitastiq won CESAward 2015 for the Best User Experience
        • Vitastiq was voted the Best Startup at the Google Campus Warsaw workshop
        • Our team’s stand was the most visited one two years in a row at the world‐renowned global nutraceutical event ‐ Vitafoods Europe in Geneva, Switzerland

        Vitastiq in the media

         

         

        How Vitastiq works?

        EAV Methodology

        With regular use, Vitastiq helps indicate the general vitamin and mineral trend. It is based on a 60-year old methodology called “Electroacupuncture according to Dr. Voll”. Vitastiq measures the electrical resistance of the skin on acupuncture points in relation to the reference point (reference point is determined during calibration). One thousand years of acupuncture experience suggests that acupuncture points differ from the surrounding skin.

         

        Pharmacists, nutritionists and other experts have been using electroacupuncture for decades to track any imbalances that might be present in the human body. So far, only impractical, large analog devices were available to them. Vitastiq has combined this well-known method with modern technology and made it accessible to everyone.

         

        Read more about the EAV method on the links below: 

        http://www.bioresonance-eav-book.com/?gclid=CKa...
        http://meridianenergies.net/research/dr-reinhar...
        http://meridianenergies.net/wp-content/uploads/...
        http://www.healthandvitaminconcepts.com/biomeri...
        http://www.doveclinic.ca/eav.htm
        http://www.wholisticresearch.com/info/artshow.p...



         

        User reviews

        Why we need your support? 

        This upgrade requires a major software adaptation and new hardware adjustments. The costs of application development are substantial, while the tools for hardware production will bring additional expenses.

        Support us once again and be one of the first owners of this cool vitamin tracker. 

        Budget calculation
         

        • iOS and Android software development: $ 10.000
        • Tools for mass production: $ 19.000
        • Total: $ 29.000 

        Timeline


        Help us create a tool that will add to your fit lifestyle!

        Ready for Stage Two?

        $129K Vitastiq Stretch Goal!

        Once we reach this milestone and raise $129,000 ($100K more than original goal) we'll start manufacturing a completely new product - VitastiqFamily! 

        You can use VitastiqFamily for yourself and your family members or friends, and keep it safely stored in an elegant plastic-coated aluminum case.   

         

        VitastiqFamily comes with an additional sonde which allows you to help someone else get their vitamin readings (as shown on the picture). 

         

         

        Together with an option to create multiple profiles within the Vitastiq app, this new product will become a perfect smart lifestyle companion of any family.

        The production has started!

         

        Assembling Vitastiq 2 at the factory.

         


        If you have any questions or need additional information, feel free to contact us on support@vitastiq.com

        Your Vitastiq team

         

        Buy It Today on the Indiegogo Marketplace!

         

        Disclaimer: App Store, iPhone, Android and iOS are the trademarks of third parties.
        Vitastiq Inc. is not affiliated with, sponsored, licensed or associated with any of these third parties.

        Vitastiq is not a medical device. It cannot prevent, treat or cure any medical problem nor can it diagnose a medical condition.

story:
In short, it's a small device that adds a layer of health security by eliminating insulin uncertainty.

Insulog™ snaps onto insulin pens to track insulin usage automatically. It’s display always shows the last insulin intake time and dosage. Plus, the data syncs to an app on your phone enabling you to browse data and share it with your medical team. Basically, It serves as an automated, technological design of that part of your brain that worries about your insulin intake.

The first thing you’ll notice when you start using Insulog is just how much time and energy you used to spend tracking your intake. Having a device tracking your intake changes a lot more than just some extra mental bandwidth; it can prevent life-threatening medical emergencies. Because for certain diabetics, a simple miscalculation or slip of the mind can result in a health scare.  

Better Diabetes Management

Diabetes maintenance is an ingrained part of a diabetic's lifestyle. It's not about drastic action, but rather maintaining a balanced diabetes.  The consistent tracking and intake awareness Insulog provides has a profound impact on your A1C and long term health and stability.

Featured on 

 

 

Insulog  Classic fits most disposable insulin pens: Flexpen (by Novonordisk ), Kwikpen (by Eli Lilly) and Solostar (Sanofi).

We've also created a wider version for the recently released FlexTouch by Novonordisk . e will contact all our backers at the end of the campaign to enable choice between the two sorts of Insulog . If you have any questions, contact us at info@insulog.life 

 

The one thing we all have in common here at Insulog is that we're all passionate about helping diabetics. That means we dedicate our time and energy to improve the lives of people suffering from diabetes, just like us.  
We created Insulog because it was really the device we wanted for ourselves, and quickly realized we had designed something truly life-changing.   
Insulog was designed to snap onto any insulin pen and slide into every diabetics’ lifestyle. And that’s something we’re really proud of. We made it for us, but not just us, all diabetics.

 

 

Insulog's app for iOS & Android serves as a hub for your intake history, usage reports and graphs. It can also sync with your Apple or Google HealthKit, pull data from your BGM and notify your doctor in a few taps of your finger.  It's the perfect companion to your Insulog device and it's currently in development.  

 

 

 

We've been working on Insulog's development for over a year. Now, the product design is ready, testing is complete, and our agreements with manufacturers is done. Now we need some funds to manufacture Insulog on a large scale, and spread the word to anyone it can help. Our last few years in a few bullet-points looks like this:

 

Menash is the heart and mind behind Insulog.  As a type 1 diabetes patient for the past 30 years, who uses disposable insulin pens at least four times a day, he fully understands the challenges of living with diabetes. For years, he managed to maintain balanced diabetes by taking painstaking notes of every intake and meal. Even so, an accidental double dose intake made him search for a better solution for insulin tracking, which ultimately lead him to  create Insulog.

Alex has years of experience in R&D with diverse fields (Medical, Robotics, Industrial, Security, Wireless & Control and Testing Systems) and led the R&D Insulog team .  Alex is also Founder & CEO of NEAT Applied Technologies.

 

Michael was manager of design for over 15 years at AVR, working with modern medical technologies. For the last 10 years, Michael has been a Project Manager at NEAT.  For the last few months he has been the lead designer at Insulog.

 

Ela is the industrial designer of Insulog. She has many years of experience in designing medical high-tech devices and adapting them to comfortable, convenient and easy consumer use. 

 

Amir has years of experience in R&D. He led the development team for Insulog's App and developed the mathematical algorithm that ensures Insulog measures accurately all insulin injections. 

 

    

 

 

FAQ

Q: What insuilin pens does Insulog work with?

A: Insulog is compatible with all major insulin pens. Insulog Classic fits the Flexpen (by Novonordisk), Kwikpen (by Eli Lilly) and Solostar (by Sanofi), and we’ve also created a wider version to fit the new FlexTouch pen by Novonordisk. You can chose the type of insulog you need during purchase.

 

Q: How long does Insulog’s charge keep?

A: Insulog’s charge keeps on average for several days.

 

Q: Can I buy two Insulogs, one for my short term insulin pen and one for my long term one? How will the information sync between them?

A: Yes, one of the perks is two Insulog’s for exactly that reason. Each Insulog will display the last intake done with the pen it’s on and on the App the information from each will be displayed separately.

 

Q: How long will Insulog last for?

A: Insulog lasts for years. It comes with a Micro USB charging cable, and it's charge last for days. Insulog is made from durable materials so you can be asure you can use it for a very long time. 

 

Q: Does the Insulog app require a setup?

A: Yes, the first time you use Insulog and the app you will choose the relevant insulin injected.

 

Q: How do I know whether Insulog is good for me?

A: If you use disposable insulin pens then Insulog is good for you. Insulog snaps on easily to insulin pens, logs automatically the time and dose of each of your intakes, displays the last intake on it’s screen, and syncs all the information to your Insulog app.

 

Q: Does the Insulog app work with both Android and iOS?

A: yes.

 

Q: Can the Insulog sync with multiple Insulog devices (for example, one for the short term pen and one for the long term one)?

A: Yes, the  app can work with two devices at the same time. The user will be able to pair different Insulog devices with different names for each insulin type so that all relevant information is synced. 

 

Q: Is Insulog easy to use?

A: Very, just snap it onto your insulin pen and never wonder when you last injected, or how much was your last dose, a quick glance at Insulog and you have all the information.

 

Q: What does the Insulog Kit include?

A: Insulog Kit includes Insulog itself, a Micro USB charging cable, a BGM-Phone sync cable (OTG) and a user guide. In addition you’ll get to choose the color of your Insulog.

 

Q: Does Insulog come in a variety of colors?

A: Yes, when you purchase you’ll be able to choose between white, chrome and blue.

 

Q: Will Insulog help me improve my A1C?

A: Absolutely, since Insulog helps you stay aware of all your intake history, it’s time and dosage, it helps understand your mistakes and helps you maintain a stable life and lower your A1C results.

 

Q: What other Apps does Insulog work with?

A: Insulog easily integrates with Apple and Google healthkits.

 

Q: Is Insulog accurate?

A: Yes, thanks to our technology, Insulog is very accurate in measuring the time and dose so that it’s safe and easy to use for every diabetic.

 

Q: How do I share information with my health care team?

A: Information is easily shared through the app.

 

Q: How does Insulog sync to the app on my phone?

A: Insulog automatically syncs all information via BLE.

 

Q: How does Insulog work?

A: Insulog is designed to fit all disposable insulin pens. A multi-sensor inside Insulog detects and counts insulin units injected. A smart software algorithm transforms the information, records and logs it on Insulog.

 

Q: What does the display screen on Insulog show?

A: The screen shows your last intake, both the time lapsed from the last injections and it’s amount.

 

Q: Can I track my glucose levels with Insulog?

A: Insulog doesn’t measure or track glucose levels, however, you will be able to transfer data from you BGM to the Insulog app via the OTG BGM-App sync cable so you can keep and share all the important information in one place.

 

Q: Why is Insulog better than writing down all the information?

A: Writing down your insulin intakes always has the risk of forgetting sometimes. Insulog automatically logs all your information, you don’t need to remember, Insulog remembers for you.

 

Q: Will Insulog be approved by FDA?

A: Yes.

 

Q: Will the cost of Insulog be covered by my medical insurance?

A: That issue will need to be clarified with your medical insurance. 

 

Q: Can Insulog measure half units?

A: For the moment, no.

 

Q: Will Insulog be produced even if it doesn't reach the campaign goal?

A: Insulog is close to our hearts and we believe will have a significant change on the lives of diabetics. For that reason, we are determined on producing Insulog. If the campaign does not reach its goal we will turn to other financial solutions and investments.

A smart software algorithm transforms the information, records and logs it on Insulog. Q: What does the display screen on Insulog show?A: The screen shows your last intake, both the time lapsed from the last injections and it’s amount. Q: Can I track my glucose levels with Insulog?A: Insulog doesn’t measure or track glucose levels, however, you will be able to transfer data from you BGM to the Insulog app via the OTG BGM-App sync cable so you can keep and share all the important information in one place. Q: Why is Insulog better than writing down all the information?A: Writing down your insulin intakes always has the risk of forgetting sometimes. Insulog automatically logs all your information, you don’t need to remember, Insulog remembers for you. Q: Will Insulog be approved by FDA?A: Yes. Q: Will the cost of Insulog be covered by my medical insurance?A: That issue will need to be clarified with your medical insurance.  Q: Can Insulog measure half units?A: For the moment, no. Q: Will Insulog be produced even if it doesn't reach the campaign goal?A: Insulog is close to our hearts and we believe will have a significant change on the lives of diabetics. For that reason, we are determined on producing Insulog. If the campaign does not reach its goal we will turn to other financial solutions and investments.

story:
Short Summary

A core team of eight people have been working on this project for two years to bring it to life.

All members of the team are knowledgeable and experienced professionals in their respective fields. Entrepreneurs with their own company, their focus is on technical architecture and engineering.

We believe that Ecomodation, in addition to addressing the habitation and accommodation needs through innovative technologies of the day, will also provide a radical contribution to the worldwide problem of energy consumption. Ecomodation will provide solutions to a myriad of problems ranging from housing refugees to living away from cities; from providing habitation modules for scientists and researchers in the field to nature lovers, vacationists, students, farmers and many others we haven’t even thought of yet.

With the help of contributors, we will be able to finance the prototyping and eventual mass production of this project. To this end, we are offering a 25% discount to our first production run.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to mass produce Ecomodation - all costs including the prototyping and setting up a production facility - we need 32,000$. We project that 12,000$ will be sufficient to cover the costs of prototyping and producing a marketable product. Once funded, the following Ecomodation modules will be available purchase:

1.Ecomodation prefabricated module

2.Solar bottle lighting module

3.Solar panel, inverter and battery systems

4.Biogas converter

5.Moisture converter

All of these modules will be available for approximately 12,000$.

Ecomodation provides a hitherto unseen solution among 100% off-the-grid systems with its ability to be fully assembled, disassembled and transported. This module only requires the imagination to use it in different variations to address all habitation needs. With ideas from our supporters for more uses for Ecomodation, we hope to build an international platform across a myriad of countries.

Once we reach enough funding to construct our prototype and move into production, we will credit all of our contributors on our website (unless, of course, they wish to remain anonymous). Additionally, the early adopter 25% discount for complete the Ecomodation suite will be available to them. If we are unable to reach our funding goals, contributors will be refunded, minus transaction costs. This is due to an unfortunate combination of circumstances of Paypal having halted its operations in Turkey on June 6th and Indiegogo only accepting Paypal as an option for “Fixed Funding” project types; this has resulted in being promissor instead of Paypal.

The Impact

Your support is of vital importance at this stage. With your support, we will be able to provide a concrete and satisfactory answer to the issue of shelter in a world increasingly developing through technology. At the most fundamental level we will be able to transform our houses from immobile to mobile. This is what’s really revolutionary about Ecomodation!

While there have been similar ideas before, Ecomodation offers a truly feasible solution.

Our project has already been met with great interest in Malta as well as İstanbul and Eskişehir in Turkey by various NGOs and municipal authorities. Ecomodation is already being talked about following its recognition in international competitions. Now we need your support for the last stretch!

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support is very important to us - but you can help us in other ways as well. Other opportunities to help us are:

●Sharing our project on social media; you can raise awareness to this project and expand our reach!

●Contact us on our website to share with us possible uses for Ecomodation in your country or city. You might even become a part of our team.

story:
About SpineHope

SpineHope is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to bringing advanced spinal treatments directly to underprivileged children around the world. Our goal is to provide state-of-the-art treatment to children who otherwise may not receive modern treatments for their complex spinal problems. In order to provide sustainable local care to these children, we are equally dedicated to teaching local physicians and staff to provide these treatments themselves. Working together with local physicians, we can correct spinal deformities, remove pain, and often prevent paralysis and extend life. We offer a domestic program that will bring select children to the United States for care in support of new sites and where there is currently not an outreach site.


About Our Hub Program

SpineHope has traditionally been recognized as a nonprofit that does work internationally, coordinating medical missions that handle complex spine deformity cases for children. But just this year SpineHope successfully launched a program (our Hub Program) in which we bring select children to Austin, TX for their spine surgical treatment. These patients come from countries where there is currently no access to adequate treatment and where there currently isn't an outreach program or medical mission that can treat them locally. 

On average, we get 1-2 cases a  month emailed to us from all over the world of patients that need help. And so, we decided that we simply cannot ignore these pleas with the heartbreaking reply of "we're sorry, but we don't have any programs in your country. Best of luck." 

One day I hope to have more sites and programs all over the globe, but right now it's a sad reality that so many requests go untreated. It sincerely breaks our hearts to limit our programs to the countries where we've set up programs. Thus, our Hub Program is our way of ethically addressing these referrals and requests for help. 

Dr. Matthew Geck, SpineHope's founder, Medical Director, and current Board Chair has dedicated years to this nonprofit and couldn't be more excited to develop this branch of our organization, state-side. After our first successful Hub patient in early 2014, Arleth Lopez (see her story here) we are confident that this program is worth the investment and commitment to these children suffering in nations without support.

The Financial Breakdown

Though we have generous donors and partners, the overall cash cost to SpineHope to make these children's dreams come true through our hub program is approximately $8,000.

SpineHope has managed to get many of the medical expenses donated, i.e. the hospital operating room, the surgeons, time, the anesthesia specialist, most x-rays, laboratory charges etc. These fees add up to tens of thousands of dollars. 

But there are additional costs that are not covered through grants or contracts. These include: 

  • Legal fees for immigration and medical visa applications and approvals.
  • All needed prescriptions pre- and post-operation.
  • International flights for patient and 1 parent, for 2-3 visits (including post-operation follow up visits to make sure there are no complications or infections from surgery approximately 4-6 months out and at 1 year after surgery).
  • Housing accommodations and food during each stay, including their 4-6 week visit for the surgery.
  • And other supplies while in-country, i.e. a welcome basket, a pre-paid phone to use while in country, transportation to medical appointments etc.

About Francisco

Since a young age Francisco has suffered from spina bifida and severe scoliosis. And though he has managed to overcome these challenges so far and make due for the first 10 years of his young life (he's really a trooper!), his condition is unfortunately only going to get worse. As he grows he may soon lose the ability to walk and so, we are desperately trying to bring him to the United States to get the surgery he needs. We have a phenomenal surgeon and partner hospital ready to take care of him as soon as possible so we can prevent any further complications and get him back on track to live a normal, happy, healthy life. 

Find out more about Francisco and our Hub Program here: http://www.spinehope.org/sponsor-me/

Challenges

Since we've launched our program mid-2013 we've quickly developed a waiting list to receive the surgeries they so desperately need. Our contracts with our partnering hospital and companies in Austin allow us to bring upwards of 10 patients a year and right now our only limitation is the funds needed to bring the children to the USA.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute a financial donation, but still feel compelled to help our cause and these children in need, please visit our website for other opportunities to get involved. Which may include:

  • Being a leader for a local Scoli-Hope Chapter.
  • Collecting orthopedic braces that we then in turn donate to our partner hospitals abroad!
  • Interning or volunteering a local fundraising event.

Please visit our website at: www.spinehope.org/get-involved/ to find out more!

story:
I'VE REACHED THIS GOAL! my intention was to pay the rest with my salary, but since I was let go- I have no money :( I've been getting food donations from friends and family and donating binders for little money. My name change has just came through and I'm still missing about 1800 IN TOTAL for my surgery (missing $1300) and for a place to stay ($350) and for my name change papers. I'm trying to find a job everyday but no one is hiring part time with my school schrdule. IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO DONATE MORE please do so.

 

If you would like a link to another donation page its right here.

 

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-last-mile/x/1504281

 

 

thank you so much for everything and what you've done. I really don't like asking for help like this but I'm desperate. Thank you SO SO SO much!

 

__________________________________________________________

 

I am having surgery May 30, 2013 in Florida with Dr. Garramone and I need your help! 

I have $2000 saved up right now, I work and saving money as well but I need help so I can reach my goal!  

Surgery cost: $5,900 USD

Bus/Flight: ~ $450

Place to stay for 8 nights: ~ $600

Food for 3 weeks in FL to recover: ~ $150

Please help me, I'm literally asking for something small, $5, $10, anything you can donate to help me.

 

I will be going to Florida for 2 weeks, I only need to stay in a place for 8 days. The other week after I am staying with family down there!

 

 

Please pass this around, I need some help since I have lots of bills to pay - cellphone, bus pass, tuition, books, credit card, food, ect....

 

**to clarify - I was asking for donations here before:

http://www.chipin.com/mypages/edit/id/a22af4eafb7ea4b0

 

but now I am asking on this page.

 

 

 

**The goal is set for April 30, 2013 - but this site doesn't let me go further than March! so you'll have an extra 1.5 month to help me!

 

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU

story:
Hello, I'm Steph Wilcock and you've reached my Indiegogo Campaign. I want to travel to Las Vegas Nevada to present a paper at the Sexual Health & Politics Conference hosted by the Desiree Alliance, July 14-19th 2013, and I've set up this appeal to raise the funds that will help me get there. 

The conference brings together people who are passionate about, and who are working towards better conditions and social status for people involved in sex work, however that may be defined, all over the world. 

Sexual freedom and rights for sex workers have long been eroded in many overt and covert ways. There are the obvious erosions that occur through governments, agencies and mainstream thinking where subjective moral values are imprinted upon policy and/or funding strategies, and there are the less obvious attacks which come from blurring the margins when discussing more sensitive topics such as (for example) trafficking, exploitation and abuse.

I've been involved in gathering a huge amount of experiences and insights into sex work since the early 1980's, where my own personal experiences led me to identify a strong desire to  connect with others who had similar stories to share. This led me to ICOP (International Conference on Prostitution) in Los Angeles in 1997, and it was here that I met many of the women and men who were to become pivotal in expanding my understanding; people like Annie Sprinkle, Carol Leigh (Scarlot Harlot), Cheryl Overs, Tracy Quan, Melissa Ditmore and many, many more. 

From that conference, I went on to establish, in association with the University Of East London, the first UK sex work conference which insisting on high (40% min) representation of current and former sex workers. This took place in September 1998 and was entitled Sex Work Reassessed. It is my view that it's not possible to discuss sex work WITHOUT the real and varied consultation of those doing the work, and anything less than this is flawed at best, and harmful and reactionary at worst. This important involvement remains a key factor in my ongoing activism.

The debate around sex work has always suffered from a dreadful polarisation of views; either we are all damned and in need of rescue or we're all happy hookers operating in the best working conditions in the world. Neither is true. As with most jobs, the range of experience is huge and can change from day to day depending on the circumstances and the people we encounter in a day's work. The point is that I firmly believe that sex workers and those working in the field of sexuality in general must be able to set our own agendas in order to work in safe and healthy ways, and that moral values have no place in deciding whether or not a person is entitled to the full protection of both the law (including employment laws) and the judicial system. 

Many sex workers feel isolated, vulnerable and fearful in their daily work. There can be massive burnout rates due to lack of mentoring and supervision, depression due to lack of peer led support and external undertanding, vulnerability due to lack of decent  health care and legal protection, and dependence due to stigma and continuing prejudice. That said, there are people out there doing incredible things to challenge and change this, but it's a long haul without the same basic rights afforded to others. 

My own perspective has changed over the years and I now work as a tantric healer, holistic therapist (I still identify as a 'sex worker') and an ongoing blogger for sexual freedom amongst many other things. I have something of value to take to this conference and to that end would like to present a paper in the arts and media stream which will focus on how we represent ourselves in this arena. I will look into how to to develop activism for social change through the arts, blogs, publishing and social networking. Sex Workers Speakeasy (the title of my paper) will be the launchpad for a cameo film project "I Have A Voice" which will be made up of short snippets of dialogue from sex and sexuality workers speaking about their key experiences, concerns, hopes and dreams in a similar style to my appeal video above. 

Initially, I need to raise around £1,500. £600 GBP for return flights, £500 GBP for accommodation, food and local travel, £300 GBP for conference fees and other expenses and £100 towards the expenses of the filmmaker for this video appeal. Without it I cannot afford to attend the conference to launch this longer term project. Your donations will be used to start the process of my project to create a great piece of work, which will support sex workers self determining in positive, healthy and dynamic ways. 

Sexual health and access to safer sex and work practices, along with a shame-free and guilt-free experience of pleasure and intimacy are our birthright.

I thank you in advance for helping me to make the world a sexier, healthier place to be!

Credentials 

Experience in many aspects of the sex industry.

Researcher and author of extensive report on Street Sex Work in Manchester, UK. 1998 for Lifeline Publications.

Author of 'On The Beat' - harm reduction leaflet for street sex workers - Lifeline Publications 1998.

Sex-Work Reassessed Conference Organiser - London, UK 1998. Also opened the conference and served as a panel member in a workshop on harmful kerb crawling initiatives.

Erotic Award nominee & finalist, category: blog, 2010

Interview on BBC Radio 4 by John Peel on my personal sex work experiences, 1999 

Contributor on Injecting Advice website: Risk Reduction for Street Sex Workers. 

Family Support Worker for young people's drug & alcohol service in Manchester.

Currently working as an holistic therapist and tantric healer.

Recently published (under the pseudonym Claudia Bellocq) the book Switchblade Sentiments. Transformative fables of a transgressive life. 

***If I exceed my goal, please note that excess funds will be used to start the film project "I Have A Voice" - thank you***

Contributor on Injecting Advice website: Risk Reduction for Street Sex Workers. 
Family Support Worker for young people's drug & alcohol service in Manchester.
Currently working as an holistic therapist and tantric healer.
Recently published (under the pseudonym Claudia Bellocq) the book Switchblade Sentiments. Transformative fables of a transgressive life. 
***If I exceed my goal, please note that excess funds will be used to start the film project "I Have A Voice" - thank you***

story:
Thank you all for taking the time to support our cause. A little over a year ago our bother Chuck completed treatment for throat cancer that was diagnosed in August 2010. Having completed an aggressive and brutal regiment of treatment that involved both radiation and chemotherapy, we were relieved and grateful for Chuck’s recovery and his return to good health and a new job. Throughout Chuck’s recovery and post treatment his dedicated and skilled oncology team monitored his recovery very closely. Regrettably, this July a new mass was detected in Chuck’s lung and as we feared, Chuck’s cancer has returned.

All of us know someone or have had a loved one or close friend who has battled this awful disease. Many of you reading this are cancer survivors yourself. Battling cancer requires enormous mental and physical strength as well as the love and support from family, friends and colleagues. Chuck is a man of great strength, purpose and dedication and we know he is going to fight with all his might to beat cancer again. Unfortunately, Chuck not only has to battle cancer, he is also battling his insurance provider, who is denying every vital test and diagnostic procedure his oncology team has deemed critical and necessary for developing a treatment protocol. In denying these tests and diagnostic procedures, his insurance carrier is putting Chuck and his family under financial duress and delaying treatment that is time critical. Medical tests and procedures conducted and administered by Chuck’s previous health care provider that were classified as routine, necessary and appropriate are shockingly regarded as experimental or unnecessary by his current insurance provider. Without an insurance life line the financial burden will become overwhelming.

While the battle rages on with the insurance company we want to raise money to offset the financial burdens that are ahead, as it is obvious the insurance company is going to do its level best to delay and deny critical care.   To us, our brother Chuck is a hero as he served our great country as a marine in the Gulf War; now he is in a war fighting Cancer and we will stand by his side.   Any amount you might be able to contribute will help.  Your contributions, well wishes and prayers are deeply appreciated by our family.

 

TRIP INSPIRATION

As brothers and best friends who share a love of the outdoors and the spectacular beauty of Colorado, Chuck and I have always dreamed of hiking the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) in Colorado, some 650 miles. The Continental Divide is the Backbone of the North American continent and divides the Pacific and Atlantic Ocean watersheds. The CDT is a 3000 mile trail that runs from the boarder of Mexico to the boarder of Canada atop the Rocky Mountains through New Mexico, Colorado, Wyoming, Utah and Montana. Each year a hand full of dedicated, some might say crazy, thru hikers hike the entire length of the CDT. Beginning Monday, July 30th myself (Jeff Botkin), my nephew and brother in-law (Adam and Kevin Jahnke) are going to hike one of the most remote and scenic sections of the Colorado CDT to raise money to help Chuck in his fight against cancer, as well as raise awareness to the unconscionable tactics and behavior of his insurance carrier. Over the course of the ten days on the trail we will hike a total of 85 mile at an average altitude of 11 thousand feet above sea level in the Weminuche Wilderness in the San Juan Mountains of Southern Colorado.

Our journey will begin at Wolf Creek Pass and conclude at Stony Pass via the Cunningham Gulch Trail that will take us into the historic mining town of Silverton, Colorado. Family and friends can track our progress via Google maps as our GSP beacon tracks our progress on the trail.

story:
What's the deal?

I've decided to bite the bullet and finally register in my first Vancouver Sun Run. Instead of just joining the anonymous hoards (almost 50,000 people ran in 2012!) I'm going to raise as much money as I can and, hopefully (see the $1000 donor perk), run it looking like a total goof. I'm putting all the money I earn towards the First United Church which operates in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside.

What is First United?

First United Church is an inner-city ministry that supports individuals living in Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside, many of whom are struggling to live with mental illness, addiction, extreme poverty, homelessness and other challenges. We seek to offer hospitality, healing, housing and social justice, in order to help people needing assistance and work with them ‘where they are at’. We offer a 60-bed homeless shelter, 2500 nutritious meals a week, a volunteer-run low-income tax program, legal advocacy, personal care services, one-on-one support, and many other day-time programs and services.

The role of First United in the community

Throughout our history of outreach and service, we have adjusted our focus to meet the changing needs of the neighbourhood, while adhering to our core goal of ‘meeting people where they are at’.

First United has a unique and comprehensive approach to connecting with homeless and vulnerable people in meaningful ways. Our holistic programming combines frontline services that meet basic human needs while ensuring people are treated with dignity; wholesome healing and recreational activities to offer an alternative to the street; and gateway services that support people’s re-integration into housing and a more stable life. Programs like meals, advocacy, mail service and dentistry are all in one place, enabling people with multiple barriers to get help when they are ready.

The Impact

Your donation will help people like:

  • P, who was able to leave his shopping cart of belongings at our secure Storage Facility while he saw a dentist for the first time in years;
  • M, who got help from our Community Workers for furniture and household items when he was moved out of a substandard single room occupancy hotel into seniors’ housing; and
  • J, 8 weeks clean, whose road to recovery started when he went from eating meals at First United to serving them as a volunteer.

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help out but can't make a donation? First United is always looking for people keen to volunteer their time and make an impact in the community.

Tax Receipt?

Please contact me directly with your details if you require a tax receipt at runningforfirst@gmail.com

story:
On Saturday, October 13th Bethany was injured while spending time with her family at the soccer jamboree in Bristol. Bethany is a loving Mom and Wife and a huge part of her community. Bethany is a soccer and basketball coach and enjoys being active!  Bethany thoroughly enjoys children and proves that by having a dynamic daycare that she runs by herself.

Bethany will be returning home the beginning of this week, but will be unable to work. Due to the injuries that Bethany has sustained she will need a recovery time of at least 6 weeks. For Bethany, recovery times means lots of UNPAID time for her and her family. This whole ordeal will also mean additional medical bills as well!

Please help support this family through this difficult time with any type of donation that you can. Any and all donations will be greatly appreciated!

 

Thank you,

Hillary Devine & Mary Jackman

story:
This is a long post but here is ..... Our Story .....{Warning may get a bit graphic} 

 My husband Douglas Todd English and I met May 28, 2004, we started dating July 4, 2004 and we were married October 22, 2005 Life was great and just seemed like it couldn't get any better.. Then April 20, 2006 (my dadâ€™s birthday) and just 6 short months after getting married He was in a major accident! Todd was a delivery driver for a HVAC supply company and was making deliveries that day. I was on my way to Birmingham to take my youngest child to a heart checkup 2 and 1/2 hours away in Birmingham (she is not Todd's child) but back to the story... It seemed like everything that could make me get behind that morning happened. I just couldn't seem to get out of town that morning and I was on the Nextel chatting back and forth with Todd that morning letting him know that we were getting ready to go and would be heading out of town shortly.. then my oldest daughter spilled something on her shirt ( another delay ) so I had to run in the thrift store and grab her a decent shirt to change into because we were already 30 minutes away from home. As I was in the store I left my phone in the truck and Todd chirped up on the Nextel and told my oldest to have me key up on him as soon as I got out of the store.. So I did, but no answer so I thought he may be at a delivery and gave him a few minutes and tried again, but again no answer so now I was getting concerned so I kept trying to key up on the Nextel but still no response back. Now Todd and I are both volunteer firefighters and I just happen to have my FD pager and radio with me that day and for some reason my pager was scanning which means that if a call goes off anywhere in the county we live in that my pager would transmit it.. and then all of a sudden the pager goes off for Killen and center star volunteer fire depts. so I just hit the reset button cause it wasn't our dept. and it was a gut feeling that was like turn that back on you want to hear that so I hit the scan button again just in time to hear the dispatcher say that those depts. needed to respond to a wreck with roll over and entrapment in front of brooks high school ( which is about where Todd should have been by that time) and all the while this was going on I was still unable to contact Todd over the phone.... so after the pager went off I decided to turn the FD scanner/walkie talkie on and listen to the call and all of a sudden I heard one of the firefighters say to the other dept. " you get that white flatbed ford right there and I will get this other truck" ok now I am franticly trying to get ahold of Todd on the phone cause that is the type of vehicle he was in that day! I still could not reach him so I called and canceled the heart doctor apt and had it rescheduled for a later date and began to drive towards the wreck scene as I was still unable to get Todd on the phone. I began to key up on the Nextel and kept calling his name and finally I heard a chirp back but my relief was short lived as the voice on the other end was not Todd and they said whom am I speaking with? And I came back, kind of choked up and said this is Todd's wife, who is this? then the response i received back was "Well this is so n so from Killen Police dept. and your husband has been in a bad wreck and the rescue crews are working to get him out of the vehicle at this time" .. Now by this time I was nearly to the accident scene so I told the police officer that and we ended the conversation then.. A few minutes later I arrived on scene and they already had him in the back of the ambulance getting him stabilized to transport to where the helicopter was landing to take him to the trauma center an hour away. I remember getting to the back of the ambulance where the back doors were open and they were working on him and he was moaning and moving around alot and then the fire chief of center star walked up to the back of the ambulance and put his arm around me as to comfort me and told the paramedics that I was his wife and as soon as they told Todd that his wife was there he quit fighting them and allowed them to work ( now he don't remember any of this till this day ) but then we drove to the helicopter landing zone and I remember standing at the back of the ambulance praying to God to not let my husband die because the Lord had just gave him to me and we had only been married 6 short months and I begged and begged God not to let him die... Then Med flight landed and the flight medic came off the helicopter and went into the ambulance to access my husband and see if he was stable enough to fly and after what seemed like an eternity the flight medic came out and walked up to me and wrapped his arm around me and looked at me and said " He is critical and if his lungs collapse do we have your permission to re-inflate them?" and I said "yes do what you have to do. So he can live!" Then they brought him out of the ambulance and rolled him to the helicopter and left. Now I still had to drive an hour to get to the hospital once I finally got there, they already had him in the trauma bay in the ER and at first they said he was to unstable for me to go back to the room and I remember sitting in the er waiting room just waiting and as family began to trickle in I told them that I still didn't know anything finally they said I could go back when I got back there they gave me a plastic cup with lid that had his bloody wedding ring that was cut in half in it and I was not ready nor prepared for what I saw! He laid there still on the back board and still in the neck brace and I broke, I began to cry he looked so awful and all cut up and the swelling had already began, his left hand was cut nearly in half down the middle and he had bleeding out of both ears (and with us both being in the EMS field I knew that bleeding from the ears was a sign of a head or brain injury and usually not a good outcome), then I began to cry more ..... I wasn't sure if I was going to lose him or not at that point. After hours in the ER room the doctor finally came in to talk to me and this is all he said â€œyour husband has a skull fracture from ear to ear across the front of his head" then he left!!! I didn't even get a chance to ask him anything! Of course my fear kicked in and I began to cry more and after 12 hours in the ER they finally moved him up to the NICU (Neurological ICU) and it was midnight by this time and they told me as soon as he was settled and stable they would come get us. We ( his dad and I) were allowed to see him for only 10 minutes that night. Then that morning around 8 we got to see him again he was awake but he didn't know who I was, but he knew his dad and people that he knew from years ago but didn't remember who I was, I was horrified! I began to think his short term memory was GONE! And that our wedding and our life together was gone too... It was like that for the next 3 days that he was in the NICU and each time I was allowed to see him I would tell him about the accident and where he was and what had happened but every time I would see him at the next visit he didnâ€™t even remember what I had just told him and then mid-morning on that 3rd day when I came in to see him in the NICU I took a deep breath ready to tell him the story again in hopes that he would remember something, especially me, but as I walked into the room he looked up and said â€œwell there's my honey" OH the relief! He remembered who I was! I was so thankful and that day they moved him into a regular room and he stayed there for 5 more days for a total of 8 days. On the 7th day they did the first surgery on his left hand to repair it. He was released the next day to rehab at home it took him nearly a month to walk again and as soon as he was back on his feet we started to church. His recovery took a year and then he went back to work and worked a short time and his injuries got worse and he was out of work for another year. His Injuries were a closed head injury, frontal skull fracture from ear to ear and fractured sinus bone on the left side of his face that was not repairable, a concussion, High frequency hearing loss in both ears, broke bones in his left hand, that required two surgeries and a titanium plate and screws to put back together and months of therapy to get back to be able to use it and still cannot fully close his hand all the way. But He was not able to go back to work in the same field as he was in and he had to learn a whole new trade. Now his medical bills totaled over $280,000 and even though we had a great attorney the state cap on a workmanâ€™s comp accident was $5,000 but they offered him $17,000 so we took it. So we are still trying to pay on the bills and loans we had to take out in order to make it while he wasnâ€™t working and that leads us to the next part of this storyâ€¦â€¦. Now that I have gotten you up to speed on the wreck situation I will tell you a bit about us wanting a baby or two. I had a partial hysterectomy on May 20, 2004 just 8 days before Todd and I met ... I had been married twice before my first husband died in a house fire and my second husband nearly killed me and the children (Just two weeks after my youngest that was 3 yrs. old at the time had heart surgery to put a pacemaker in) and he is currently sitting in Mississippi prison. So I had 2 children by each marriage and Todd knew this when we got married and we once we were married we began to put money away out of each paycheck to begin saving for a surrogate mother to carry our baby (embryo - my egg and his sperm ) but after the wreck the little bit of money that we had in savings had to be used to live on while he was out of work and now we have tried to get back on our feet and get the funds back up but we just can't seem to be able to. I have researched the cost and it is a min of $30,000 for a surrogate mom to carry our child plus the hospital bill for the delivery so that is why our goal is set at $51,000 I understand times are hard but if just 51,000 people would donate just $1 we could have our dream and give this selfless man a gift of his own ( a biological child ) He was so selfless coming into this marriage knowing that we would not be able to have children the normal way but now even the dream we had of having a child has been taken from us. This is why I have come here to ask of you all to help us to achieve that goal. You can follow our journey as it unfolds on our Facebook page so each person that donates to our cause can follow the story and know that the money you share from your heart will be used for this process only. I would love for nothing more than to give my husband the thing he desires most and that is to become a "dad" As my youngest was 5yrs old when Todd and I met. Thank you for your time in reading this story of our life and thank you in advance for your donation to help fund our dream of being parents. If any of you want to see pictures of the wrecked truck that he was in and the truck that hit him and pictures of him after he was out of NICU and in a regular room or follow us just follow this link to our Facebook page that was created for this journey. Here is the link .... http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=10000328... If for some reason we do not raise the whole amount of money it takes to pay for the surrogate and the delivery of our baby, our next choice will be to take the funds raised to adopt a newborn baby. I believe our goal will be met because Todd is a selfless man and He loves unconditionally and I know our Lord will reward that and we will met or exceed our goal and be blessed with our miracle. I thank all of you for being a part in that, and helping make our dream come true. May the Lore richly bless each of you that donate and those of you who pray for our family as well.
