Thankyou!

story:
My Story (tl;dr at the bottom)

Hello IndieGoGo, my name is Katherine. I'm 20 years old, and you could say I'm not the average young adult. In my freshman year of high school, I began to suffer from panic attacks and anxiety, two illnesses that severely disrupted my life and have plagued me ever since. Over the years as my anxiety increased and became a more and more daunting aspect of my life, I began to slip in and out of depression. 


The past year and a half has been particularly trying. In the fall of 2010 I went away to college. It was the first time I had ever lived away from home and, although it wasn't all that far from my hometown, I started to feel the depression hovering over me. Things were rough. I wasn't sure if I was going to be able to even complete my first semester, but I pressed on.


And that's when the sh*t hit the fan. Or, in actuality, that's when the car hit the guardrail. 


In the first week of December my boyfriend and I were driving back to school. Now, I have never been a fan of snow and, unfortunately, being from upstate New York, the majority of my life has been buried under snow. Looking back, I should've known not to go out that Monday morning. It was snowing pretty heavily, but my boyfriend assured me everything would be fine (he had taken Driver's Ed during the winter) and we headed out.


As we rounded the first corner and the back wheels fishtailed, the tears started streaming. I was ready to give up and hightail it back home. But we kept going. 


Even now as I'm typing this and reliving that morning, my hands are shaking and I am near tears. We successfully made is across the Bay Bridge (the bridge spanning Irondequoit Bay) somehow, but that's when our luck ran out. In an attempt to change lanes, the car hit a patch of ice and we lost control. We spun twice and hit the guardrail, and landed facing oncoming traffic. 


And that's when I lost it. I started screaming and crying at the same time and simply couldn't stop. I'm sure I scared my boyfriend just as much as I scared myself. However strange it sounds, I felt betrayed by the car. I had never been in a car crash before and the feeling of being in an out-of-control vehicle was the worst thing I'd ever felt. 


Thankfully, we weren't hurt besides a bit of whiplash, but I had no idea how badly that crash would effect me. For days afterword, every time I closed my eyes I was back in the car, spinning and crashing. We would later find out that the crash caused me to develop Post Traumatic Stress Disorder or PTSD, which I still have to this day.


After many calls to our parents and to AAA, a tow truck was able to turn the car around and my dad -- thank goodness for him -- came to pick me up and take me home. 


As you can imagine, this made the last few weeks of the semester almost unbearable. Two rocky weeks passed, and with one week left I could see the end in sight. But on the final Sunday night that I returned to my dorm, I woke up in the middle of the night feeling extremely sick to my stomach. My anxiety immediately went through the roof. 


You see, when my anxiety first started, it came along with an extreme fear of vomiting. To make a long story short, I spent that night sleeping in front of the toilet. 


I honestly don't know how I made it through that last week of school. I refused to eat or drink a single thing the entire week. I figured if I didn't eat anything, I couldn't get sick. And it worked, but unfortunately it would turn into another problem in the long run. I was shaken to my core and I felt so vulnerable. I was scared by how I was acting and how much I was crying.


Finishing out the semester, I was able to go home and attempt to enjoy the winter holidays. I had it in my head that if I could just make it back home, everything would be alright. Unfortunately, it wasn't. 


Over the last week of school, my stomach had shrunk, my anxiety medication had worn off (I had been too afraid to take my pills), and my panic attacks had returned full force. Christmas day included several panic attacks and constant anxiety. 


As my next semester at school loomed near, my parents and I decided it would be best if I dropped out of school and came home. So we emptied my dorm room and I moved back home. Although I wasn't eating much, things were going okay. Not good, but okay.


And that's when the sh*t hit the fan again.


One morning in January I woke up with the worst pain I had EVER felt radiating from my hip. I was suddenly nauseous, extremely warm, sweating, and shaking. I ran to the bathroom, extremely confused and scared about what was going on. I was literally so warm I took off my shirt and was hanging out the window in the cold winter air. 


My mother came home, took one look at me, and rushed me to the emergency room (against my wishes because it was snowing, but I am extremely thankful she made me go). I spent 6 hours in the hospital being poked and prodded as the doctors tried to figure out what was wrong with me. Due to dehydration, I was hooked up to a saline drip and then given an ultrasound. 


As they scanned my insides, I saw confusion flash across the technician's face. He pressed hard beneath my ribs and asked, "Does this hurt?" Feeling no pain, I answered that it didn't. Eventually, the doctors came to the conclusion that, because I hadn't been drinking enough water, especially in the last week of school, I had passed a large kidney stone. Because the stone had passed, I was released from the hospital and went home.


The next day we saw my pediatrician for a follow-up appointment and as he looked over my file he seemed concerned. He told us that during the ultrasound while they were looking at my kidneys, they had also found gallstones. But we were told that since they hadn't caused me any pain so far they most likely wouldn't be a problem. Unfortunately, that information was very, very wrong.      


January turned into February and things were okay. I spent most of my time in my room, sleeping. Spending time outside my room made me panicky so I became very isolated. I hated even seeing the snow outside my window, so I kept my curtains drawn. I was extremely depressed when I was awake and I only found comfort in sleeping. Unfortunately it went on like this for a while.


February turned into March and I was dealt another challenge: I experienced three kidney stones passing over the course of one weekend. I found myself in the ER again, this time being treated by a disbelieving nurse who thought I was only there trying to get narcotics. After a long, painful night, I was allowed to go home.


I was referred to a nephrologist and blood work was ordered. My calcium levels were slightly elevated and there was a possibility that I might've had a thyroid problem. Thankfully, a test for that came back negative and I was sent home.


It was around that time that I was referred to a psychologist and I started meeting with her. By the time I started seeing her I had lost a considerable amount of weight due to strange stomach pains I had been experiencing ever since that last week of school. It wasn't that I didn't want to eat, it was that I physically couldn't. Although I explained this concept to the psychologist, she referred me to a local hospital with a teenage-eating-disorder program. 


I went there hoping that someone could explain to me why my stomach was hurting so much and how I could fix it. What I encountered was an extremely degrading environment. As soon as I walked through the door, I was seen as an anorexic teenage girl. No matter how many times I tried to explain to the doctors that I physically couldn't stomach any foods, they still saw me through their tunnel vision.


Every time I went, I was required to strip naked, put on a hospital gown and get weighed. A male nurse even checked underneath my gown to make sure I wasn't hiding lead weights in my panties.


There was one certain nurse who I clashed with the worst. We danced around the subject in our conversations, but overall she pretty much called me a liar to my face. She told me that I COULD eat and that I was trying to lose weight on purpose. 


In our final visit, her and another doctor with the same attitude told me to drink a glass of Ensure, which is a drink high in calories they give to patients who can't keep food down. I argued with them, telling them that those drinks made me sick (which they do) and that it would really hurt my stomach. After many tears shed and being told I was lying, I was literally forced to drink the stuff. I left there that day with my mascara running, feeling sick to my stomach, and vowing to never go back there.    


It was literally the next weekend that my grandmother passed away. She had been to the doctor and told that she had two types of cancer and might live another six months. She only lasted one. 


That was when I pretty much stopped eating. The pains and nausea my stomach was causing was almost unbearable. For weeks I was only able to eat three Fig Newtons a day. Things were getting serious.


As quick as possible we went to see a gastroenterologist, who, after meeting with me once and pressing on my belly, knew something was physically wrong. Although something was wrong with me, it was almost a relief. Finally after months of pain and being told it was all in my head, we finally had something to act on. Answers were coming.


Four days later, I was in the hospital having an endoscopy. The gastroenterologist decided they would look in my stomach to see if I had an ulcer. If it wasn't that, then it was most likely a problem with my gallbladder. 


Sure enough, my stomach was fine. It had been my gallbladder the entire time. The gallbladder I had been told that shouldn't be a problem.


In June, I met with a surgeon and a week later I was being prepped for surgery. It was one of the most nerve-wracking days of my life. Hospitals have always been a source of stress and I had never needed surgery before. My stomach was completely empty and yet I nearly threw up. 


Recovering from the surgery was possibly even more painful then the kidney stones. But thankfully, the recovery time was quick and suddenly, like some sort of miracle, I could eat again. Not much, but more than three Fig Newtons. After losing 90 -- yes, I said 90 -- pounds, and shrinking 14 pants sizes, the physical maladies had seemed to come to an end.      


Unfortunately, the mental illness still remained.


Over the summer, my boyfriend and I found an apartment close to school so we wouldn't have to commute so far. Things were doing pretty well. We moved all our stuff in, bought our textbooks, and waited for the end of August. Around the same time, I started meeting with a psychiatrist who I was able to connect with much easier. School started and I managed not to pass out on the first day (although I almost did). I was cautious not to jinx it, but things were going rather good. 


Over time though, going back every Sunday night got harder and harder. Every week I grew more homesick, missing my family and the house I'd lived in my entire life. I began to skip classes, not being able to convince myself to go. The stress of catching up was starting to creep up on me and I could tell a mental breakdown was imminent. 


Somehow, I persevered and finished a second semester. I had made it through again. Unfortunately, my grades took a hit because of all the classes I'd missed, but I still passed.


From the moment I got home for Christmas break, the thought of going back was weighing on my mind. All I wanted was to stay home where I belonged. But I knew if I didn't go back to school I would be letting a lot of people down. For weeks it felt like my brain was trying to rip itself apart. 


So I went back.


I knew from my first day of classes that this wasn't going to work. I decided to try cutting my work load in half, so I dropped three of my classes. That worked for a little while, but I soon found myself crying at the thought of returning to school. It was an excruciatingly painful decision, but I knew what I had to do.  


So now, here I am again. The story has come full circle. 


I dropped out of school and am still getting help for my anxiety and depression. But I know I need to help myself too.


HERE'S THE IMPORTANT PART:

One thing that has always made me happy from the moment I discovered it is the video game 'Portal' and it's sequel 'Portal 2'. I have always been a gamer, but I have never found a game I loved as much as this one. 


Lately, I have been starving for some creative outlet; something to help ease my anxiety. Ever since I graduated from high school, I haven't taken any art courses and I feel severely burnt out. 


Ever since seeing photos on the web of people redesigning their rooms to be Portal-themed, I've wanted to do the same. I have so many creative ideas my brain is ready to bust. Only thing is, my family has always been low-income and because of my (hopefully) temporary disability, I can't work at this point. 


I think making over my room would be extremely soothing and therapeutic, that's why I'm hoping maybe you guys could help me out :)


(tl;dr: I am a girl who's been suffering from anxiety and depression for years now, and I think making my room over to be Portal-themed will be extremely beneficial and therapeutic.)  


The Impact

I've spent a good amount of time dreaming up what I'd like my room to look like, and here's what I've come up with:


[Entry Door Wall]  |  [Inset Shelves Wall]  |  [Double Window Wall]  |  [Closet Door Wall]


And, no, I'm not asking you guys to buy me a Portal gun :) My mom pre-ordered it for me and I'm paying her back with babysitting my sister


Doing this project would be such a dream come true! Lately, Portal is the only thing that makes me happy and I really want to expand my creativity. I miss creating art and expressing who I am. I think this will help quell the storm in my mind. 


What I Need & What You Get

I think for this project I'll need about $2,000. I know its kind of a lot, but I have some really fun ideas :)


Here's a list of some of the things I hope to buy: 

 


  • - Orange Life Preserver [for Borealis buoy] - $32.50 + cost of paint + lettering
  • - "Moon in My Room" [to replicate the Moon from the end of Portal 2] – $19.54
  • - Orange LED Rope (10 ft) [For orange glowing mirror] - $18.56
  • - Blue LED Rope (10 ft) [For blue glowing mirror]  - $22.33
  • - Cave Johnson Talking Portrait - $39.99
  • - Aperture Labs Endorsement Posters - $14.95
  • - 15” x 22” Oval Mirror [to make glowing Portal mirror] – $18.60
  • - Red Circle Bath Rug [to pretend its a Heavy Duty Super Colliding Super Button] - $9.99
  • - Nightstand decals [for Turret nightstand] - $149.95
  • - Artograph Tracer Junior 10x Projector [for tracing the murals onto the walls] - ~$50
  • - Many different color paints - [not sure how much this will cost]    
  • - Stuff for Test Chamber sign - [I've made something similar to this before, I think it'll cost ~$50]
  • - Fake plants for foliage - ~$90
  • - Green thumbtacks [for posing foliage] - $0.69
  • - Artificial stuffed crow - $17.98
  • - 6" Clear PVC Pipe [for cube transport tubes]- ~$100
  • - 4pk 8" x 10" Document Frames [for Cave Johnson awards] - $15.97
  • - Lumber, PVC pipe, paint, hardware + plexiglass for Portal Gun stand [not sure how much this will cost]
  • - Orange and Blue paint for gel splatters
  • - Gray, yellow + misc paints for the walls
  • - Lumber for Turret box nightstand
  • - Some sort of lighting for GLaDOS's eye
  • - Puck lighting kits [for the 'Completion Sign'] - $255
  • - Touch lights for illuminating Cave Johnson awards
  • - 6 Replica potatoes [for making PotatOS/GLaDOS] - $18.00
  • - Portal 2 PotatOS Science kit - $24.99
  • - 12" x 12" Orange plexiglass [for completion sign] - $6.69
  • - Decals for Test Chamber sign
  • - Vinyl decals for glowing mirrors 
  • - 'GLaDOS Emergency Shutdown' print
  • - Fabric for Aperture waiting room curtains

 


I'm not really sure if I'll be able to do any perks, which kinda stinks :( The only thing I could give you would be my undying thanks, which I would do :)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you guys can't donate that's completely fine, but if you find something on my list for a cheaper price or something and you could point me in the right direction that would be wonderful :) Also, if you could pass along the link that would be amazing :)

He told us that during the ultrasound while they were looking at my kidneys, they had also found gallstones. But we were told that since they hadn't caused me any pain so far they most likely wouldn't be a problem. Unfortunately, that information was very, very wrong.      

January turned into February and things were okay. I spent most of my time in my room, sleeping. Spending time outside my room made me panicky so I became very isolated. I hated even seeing the snow outside my window, so I kept my curtains drawn. I was extremely depressed when I was awake and I only found comfort in sleeping. Unfortunately it went on like this for a while.

February turned into March and I was dealt another challenge: I experienced three kidney stones passing over the course of one weekend. I found myself in the ER again, this time being treated by a disbelieving nurse who thought I was only there trying to get narcotics. After a long, painful night, I was allowed to go home.

I was referred to a nephrologist and blood work was ordered. My calcium levels were slightly elevated and there was a possibility that I might've had a thyroid problem. Thankfully, a test for that came back negative and I was sent home.

It was around that time that I was referred to a psychologist and I started meeting with her. By the time I started seeing her I had lost a considerable amount of weight due to strange stomach pains I had been experiencing ever since that last week of school. It wasn't that I didn't want to eat, it was that I physically couldn't. Although I explained this concept to the psychologist, she referred me to a local hospital with a teenage-eating-disorder program. 

I went there hoping that someone could explain to me why my stomach was hurting so much and how I could fix it. What I encountered was an extremely degrading environment. As soon as I walked through the door, I was seen as an anorexic teenage girl. No matter how many times I tried to explain to the doctors that I physically couldn't stomach any foods, they still saw me through their tunnel vision.

Every time I went, I was required to strip naked, put on a hospital gown and get weighed. A male nurse even checked underneath my gown to make sure I wasn't hiding lead weights in my panties.

There was one certain nurse who I clashed with the worst. We danced around the subject in our conversations, but overall she pretty much called me a liar to my face. She told me that I COULD eat and that I was trying to lose weight on purpose. 

In our final visit, her and another doctor with the same attitude told me to drink a glass of Ensure, which is a drink high in calories they give to patients who can't keep food down. I argued with them, telling them that those drinks made me sick (which they do) and that it would really hurt my stomach. After many tears shed and being told I was lying, I was literally forced to drink the stuff. I left there that day with my mascara running, feeling sick to my stomach, and vowing to never go back there.    

It was literally the next weekend that my grandmother passed away. She had been to the doctor and told that she had two types of cancer and might live another six months. She only lasted one. 

That was when I pretty much stopped eating. The pains and nausea my stomach was causing was almost unbearable. For weeks I was only able to eat three Fig Newtons a day. Things were getting serious.

As quick as possible we went to see a gastroenterologist, who, after meeting with me once and pressing on my belly, knew something was physically wrong. Although something was wrong with me, it was almost a relief. Finally after months of pain and being told it was all in my head, we finally had something to act on. Answers were coming.

Four days later, I was in the hospital having an endoscopy. The gastroenterologist decided they would look in my stomach to see if I had an ulcer. If it wasn't that, then it was most likely a problem with my gallbladder. 

Sure enough, my stomach was fine. It had been my gallbladder the entire time. The gallbladder I had been told that shouldn't be a problem.

In June, I met with a surgeon and a week later I was being prepped for surgery. It was one of the most nerve-wracking days of my life. Hospitals have always been a source of stress and I had never needed surgery before. My stomach was completely empty and yet I nearly threw up. 

Recovering from the surgery was possibly even more painful then the kidney stones. But thankfully, the recovery time was quick and suddenly, like some sort of miracle, I could eat again. Not much, but more than three Fig Newtons. After losing 90 -- yes, I said 90 -- pounds, and shrinking 14 pants sizes, the physical maladies had seemed to come to an end.      

Unfortunately, the mental illness still remained.

Over the summer, my boyfriend and I found an apartment close to school so we wouldn't have to commute so far. Things were doing pretty well. We moved all our stuff in, bought our textbooks, and waited for the end of August. Around the same time, I started meeting with a psychiatrist who I was able to connect with much easier. School started and I managed not to pass out on the first day (although I almost did). I was cautious not to jinx it, but things were going rather good. 

Over time though, going back every Sunday night got harder and harder. Every week I grew more homesick, missing my family and the house I'd lived in my entire life. I began to skip classes, not being able to convince myself to go. The stress of catching up was starting to creep up on me and I could tell a mental breakdown was imminent. 

Somehow, I persevered and finished a second semester. I had made it through again. Unfortunately, my grades took a hit because of all the classes I'd missed, but I still passed.

From the moment I got home for Christmas break, the thought of going back was weighing on my mind. All I wanted was to stay home where I belonged. But I knew if I didn't go back to school I would be letting a lot of people down. For weeks it felt like my brain was trying to rip itself apart. 

So I went back.

I knew from my first day of classes that this wasn't going to work. I decided to try cutting my work load in half, so I dropped three of my classes. That worked for a little while, but I soon found myself crying at the thought of returning to school. It was an excruciatingly painful decision, but I knew what I had to do.  

So now, here I am again. The story has come full circle. 

I dropped out of school and am still getting help for my anxiety and depression. But I know I need to help myself too.

HERE'S THE IMPORTANT PART:
One thing that has always made me happy from the moment I discovered it is the video game 'Portal' and it's sequel 'Portal 2'. I have always been a gamer, but I have never found a game I loved as much as this one. 

Lately, I have been starving for some creative outlet; something to help ease my anxiety. Ever since I graduated from high school, I haven't taken any art courses and I feel severely burnt out. 

Ever since seeing photos on the web of people redesigning their rooms to be Portal-themed, I've wanted to do the same. I have so many creative ideas my brain is ready to bust. Only thing is, my family has always been low-income and because of my (hopefully) temporary disability, I can't work at this point. 

I think making over my room would be extremely soothing and therapeutic, that's why I'm hoping maybe you guys could help me out :)

(tl;dr: I am a girl who's been suffering from anxiety and depression for years now, and I think making my room over to be Portal-themed will be extremely beneficial and therapeutic.)  



The Impact
I've spent a good amount of time dreaming up what I'd like my room to look like, and here's what I've come up with:

[Entry Door Wall]  |  [Inset Shelves Wall]  |  [Double Window Wall]  |  [Closet Door Wall]

And, no, I'm not asking you guys to buy me a Portal gun :) My mom pre-ordered it for me and I'm paying her back with babysitting my sister

Doing this project would be such a dream come true! Lately, Portal is the only thing that makes me happy and I really want to expand my creativity. I miss creating art and expressing who I am. I think this will help quell the storm in my mind. 



What I Need & What You Get
I think for this project I'll need about $2,000. I know its kind of a lot, but I have some really fun ideas :)

Here's a list of some of the things I hope to buy: 
 


- Orange Life Preserver [for Borealis buoy] - $32.50 + cost of paint + lettering
- "Moon in My Room" [to replicate the Moon from the end of Portal 2] – $19.54
- Orange LED Rope (10 ft) [For orange glowing mirror] - $18.56
- Blue LED Rope (10 ft) [For blue glowing mirror]  - $22.33
- Cave Johnson Talking Portrait - $39.99
- Aperture Labs Endorsement Posters - $14.95
- 15” x 22” Oval Mirror [to make glowing Portal mirror] – $18.60
- Red Circle Bath Rug [to pretend its a Heavy Duty Super Colliding Super Button] - $9.99
- Nightstand decals [for Turret nightstand] - $149.95
- Artograph Tracer Junior 10x Projector [for tracing the murals onto the walls] - ~$50
- Many different color paints - [not sure how much this will cost]    
- Stuff for Test Chamber sign - [I've made something similar to this before, I think it'll cost ~$50]
- Fake plants for foliage - ~$90
- Green thumbtacks [for posing foliage] - $0.69
- Artificial stuffed crow - $17.98
- 6" Clear PVC Pipe [for cube transport tubes]- ~$100
- 4pk 8" x 10" Document Frames [for Cave Johnson awards] - $15.97
- Lumber, PVC pipe, paint, hardware + plexiglass for Portal Gun stand [not sure how much this will cost]
- Orange and Blue paint for gel splatters
- Gray, yellow + misc paints for the walls
- Lumber for Turret box nightstand
- Some sort of lighting for GLaDOS's eye
- Puck lighting kits [for the 'Completion Sign'] - $255
- Touch lights for illuminating Cave Johnson awards
- 6 Replica potatoes [for making PotatOS/GLaDOS] - $18.00
- Portal 2 PotatOS Science kit - $24.99
- 12" x 12" Orange plexiglass [for completion sign] - $6.69
- Decals for Test Chamber sign
- Vinyl decals for glowing mirrors 
- 'GLaDOS Emergency Shutdown' print
- Fabric for Aperture waiting room curtains



 

I'm not really sure if I'll be able to do any perks, which kinda stinks :( The only thing I could give you would be my undying thanks, which I would do :)



Other Ways You Can Help
If you guys can't donate that's completely fine, but if you find something on my list for a cheaper price or something and you could point me in the right direction that would be wonderful :) Also, if you could pass along the link that would be amazing :)

story:
In Short

Tristian is a year and a half old and has bone cancer.  He's just had surgery to remove a tumor in his leg.  Your support makes a difference.  He needs help.  He needs you. 

UPDATE!

Tristian's surgery is complete and everything went as expected.  He had a bit of a fever after but it seems to have gone down.

We know that every penny of this campaign is going to help he and his parents stay in Toronto be comfortable so that the focus can be on Tristian getting better instead of finances.

Thank you to everyone who is supporting Tristian and his parents by contributing, spreading his campaign, and keeping them all in your thoughts.

Tristian's Story

Tristian James had always been a happy little boy.  Smiling, dancing, and bubbling with personality and infectious laughter.  When he began to stop placing weight on his leg and cried out in pain when he was picked up, his family knew something was wrong.  At the first visit to the emergency room the doctors thought it was only an infection.  Then over a week later the final diagnosis came in, the word that stopped his parents hearts.  Cancer.

A malignant tumor was found in his left femur.  Agonizing weeks of waiting and it was identified; Ewings Sarcoma, an extremely rare form of bone cancer nearly unheard of in kids his age.  Two-thirds of his left femur is affected by the tumor.  He has started on chemotherapy to try to stop the aggressive cancer from spreading.  So far luck is on his side.

Tristian still needs surgery to remove the tumor.  A very special operation might even be able to save his leg.  There are no specialists in Saskatchewan able to handle this delicate procedure.

Your Contribution

Your contribution will help cover the costs of travel for his parents.  Tristian's surgery takes place in Toronto and they will be unable to bring him home for at least three weeks after the operation.  Contributions will also ease extra medical expenses like prescriptions and parking and help to balance the loss of one full income in the household as Tristian's mom is always up at the hospital with him.  This will be even more strained when they are both in Toronto and away from home and work.

The financial burdens placed on his family will only increase as his fight goes on. 

Any contribution big or small will make a huge difference in this little boy's life.  Even $1.00 is a treasure.

Any funds that are raised over and above what will help these short term goals will be placed in trust for Tristian for any other medical expenses that may arise.  Should this battle with cancer be beaten back quickly any remaining funds will be held in the trust for a college education for Tristian.

Importance

Tristian doesn't even realize that he is battling a life threatening condition and continues to be a beacon of light and happiness for those that are suffering alongside him.  Please contribute your support to this little boy and keep a smile on his face.

Our Heartfelt Thanks

Thank you on behalf of Tristian and all of his family and friends for any contribution you can give, even if it's as simple as raising awareness for this fundraiser or Ewings Sarcoma itself.  We would also like to request that everyone out there take a moment to hug someone they care about, you never know when it might be your last chance.

story:
Short Summary

Join OMG! Organic Meets Good in creating the first ever quinoa based protein powder. Our formula is organic, vegan, delicious and convenient to use. It’s for conscious people who care about their wellness and want a protein boost from superfoods like quinoa, hemp, coconut and sacha inchi, collected directly from places where they originate. The combination of these ingredients makes it easy to digest. It is the ideal complement to a vegan or vegetarian diet or people with intolerance to other sources of protein. It boasts natural sweeteners and is non-GMO, vegan, 100% organic, gluten free and allergen free. 

With our delicious protein powder, you will find a delightful way to add 10.5 grams of organic protein to your body per 30g serving. It will be available in both as a stand-up pouch with 15 servings per package and a box with 12 single serve pouches. It is a convenient way to superfood your day by adding protein to your beverages and meals at home or on the go. 

    

OMG! Organic Meets Good offers superfood powders made with a fusion of food-based nutrients from around the globe, such as Maqui Berries from Chile, quinoa and sacha inchi directly from the producers in Peru. We currently have two delicious products in the market:

·  OMG Antioxidant Powder with Maqui Berry, green tea extract and acai berry

·  OMG Vitamin Powder with pomegranate, maqui berry and Camu Camu.

All our powders are 100% organic, vegan, kosher, and gluten-free, and can be added to any of your daily beverages and meals for healthy boost. We are always suggesting new and fun ways to use our products. They can be mixed into cereals, smoothies, shakes, bars, and more. Check out our Recipes and discover several new and innovative ways to use these amazing powders!

Our formulas and products are made with passion, a strong sense of social-consciousness, and nutrients that are beneficial to your well being.

We strive to make living organically and actively much simpler. 

   

To accomplish our goals to make this product available for you, we are looking to raise $15,000. This funding amount will cover the cost of the ingredients and packaging material for the first batch of production. 

Please be the first to try our unique protein product and select your prefer perk package. Try our complete line of superfood boosting powders and make sure to share and spread it with love to family and friends.

Help us achieve dreams to bring this delicious superfood fusion to the market!


v   

 Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign everywhere! Muchas gracias and superfood your day!!

Do you want to know more about the story behind our company? Check out this video!

story:
In 2009 Gerry was first diagnosed with Colon/Rectal Cancer. After months of chemo/radiation he had his first surgery. Then about a year later, he found out that his cancer was back. He was out of work again and had yet another surgery.

 

Now in January of this year the cancer spread to his liver and had half of his liver removed. He was out of work without pay for 10 weeks. He was told in August that his cancer was back again in his rectal area. He can no longer work due to cancer and chemo. Surgery can not be done close to home and he has to travel to Illinois for surgery and treatment. He has yet another long road ahead of recovery and treatment.

 

Due to this yet another reoccurrence of cancer he is struggling financially to keep his family going and accumulating medical costs Please share this with your family and friends. We know that this is a tough time financially for everyone, but every little bit counts. Thank you and God Bless.

story: Linda Sales is a wonderful mother of 4, grandmother of 4, a loving wife for 35 years and a caring nurse for over 30 years whose life got turned upside down when she was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer in March 2011. In April she began the fight of her life going through 2 separate surgeries, 5 months of intense chemotherapy and 6 weeks of radiation 5 days a week. My mother has always put her family and her patients she cared for first and for the first time had to learn to put herself and her health first and let her family give and care for her as she has done for everyone else her whole life. Up to this point my father had been unemployed due to lack of work in construction for numerous years and were even struggling at that point to make ends meet. Upon my mothers diagnosis she was forced to go on short and long term disability from her stable job she has been with for over 20 years to focus on beating this battle with cancer. All that mattered was being cancer free and beating this battle. She stayed strong through this trying time and will always remain, in my eyes, one of the strongest people I have ever met. She completed her treatment plan just a few days before Christmas 2011 and is now trying to get her life back in order. The company she has worked so hard for, for the last 21 years, is giving her 30 days to find a job within their company or else she will be terminated. She has been on long term disability and was told she is guaranteed a job, but there being no open positions for her job title, it doesn't look promising. My parents are struggling to pay their monthly bills and pay the numerous amount of medical bills that stacked up during my mothers treatments. I am reaching out to family, friends and to the general public to please help raise money to try and release the burden that has been put on them due to my mothers diagnosis with breast cancer and the treatments that were required to save her life. A donation account has been set up in her name, Linda Sales, and we would greatly appreciate any assistance you can contribute. Any donation big or small will definitely not go unnoticed. Thank you.

story:
As a stay at home mom I decided to step up and give a hand to a close friend, who is also a stay at home mom of 4 young children, who just found out recently that she has a colorectal cancer stage T3 ..Fatima is such a great human being that her generosity has touched so many people before. She is in a hospital bed trying to figure out how she can fight cancer without having insurance or a good income. Her husband is a contractor and has limited wages .Her kids are still in school and have no way of helping her out. Her bills are piling up and adding an extra stress. I decided to put this fundraiser in order to ease some of this stress and allow Fatima to have a little peace of mind while dealing with Chemo and radiation. Any collected amount will be used to pay Fatima’s bills (Medication, Rent, Electricity, Gas, medical procedures and after care). I can provide any type of verification if you would like to make sure that this Fundraising is legit.  

 There is no small or big donation, any amount will be greatly appreciated even if it’s $1, your support will also give this family hope and comfort knowing that they aren’t alone in this fight and there is an army of great hearts behind them so please don’t forget to send your prayers as well...They are as helpful as any financial donation.  

"Real generosity is doing something nice for someone who will never find it
out."
-- Frank A. Clark

story:
Camp gives him hope and each year, when he comes away from his camp experience, he stands taller, walks prouder, talks more, and smiles a TON! 

Regardless, the social support and skills that he gains at camp directly translate into greater success at school, increased confidence, and better relationships.

story:
FIRST:

Thank-you for taking the time to visit this page;  I am not an athlete...anyone who knows me knows this. Witnessing my cousin's positive attitude through his struggle and knowing how his life has changed, has inspired me to use my body in ways we don’t appreciate until they are gone.  

"I am only one, but still I am one. I cannot do everything, but still I can do something; and because I cannot do everything, I will not refuse to do something that I can do."

Helen Keller

Kevin's Story and the beginning of Walk It Off

This story is among one of the many that starts as a fun filled day and ends in tragedy. While celebrating a family wedding on the beach in Cuba, February 2009, my cousin Kevin Mills, age 28 at the time, was driven head first into the sand by a wave. Luckily, his new brother-in-law was able to pull him out of the water and to safety. Kevin broke his neck, sustaining a Spinal Cord Injury (SCI), was diagnosed a C4 ASIA A, quadriplegic and had no feeling or movement below the shoulders. Kevin and his wife Heather were both Advanced Care Paramedics in Toronto and now have experienced the medical system as both providers and patients. They have learned through our experiences that you must seek out and strive to provide the best care possible for your loved ones. They found that care at a SCI Recovery Centre in California, called Project Walk. They felt this specialized program should be available to our community and so began the process of building this unique not-for-profit SCI recovery centre, serving all of Ontario and beyond. 

**Note:  THE VIDEO ATTACHED SHOWS PEOPLE'S EXPERIENCES AND EXPLAINS WHY THE MONEY IS NEEDED FOR THE FES BIKE.  Please ignore the Aviva plea on the video.  Walk It Off unfortunately did not receive funding via Aviva and thus why I am doing this to help them still try and raise the much needed funds. 

What We Need & What You Get

Walk it off is in desperate need of very expensive specialized equipment to assist with their recovery program.  

ALL funds raised through this campaign will go towards this equipment. Every little bit helps. Your funds will assist someone with a spinal cord injury to live their fullest quality of life and maybe even one day a possible recovery. 

The Impact

There are 85,556 Canadians living with SCI and 4257 occurrences every year. Though SCIs can affect all ages, eighty-four percent of people who sustain a SCI are under 34 years of age. Because SCIs have such an impact on our youth, we intend to develop a SCI prevention and awareness program designed for our high schools. 

Traditional SCI rehabilitation is designed to help people function to the maximum with their disability. Traditionally, very little is asked of the paralyzed nervous system and muscles. Clients at WALK IT OFF will receive training by SCI Recovery Specialists who stimulate the nervous system and perform repetitive, manual manipulation of the paralyzed areas of the body with intense core retraining. This approach is known as the Dardzinski MethodTM of Spinal Cord Injury Recovery developed by Project Walk. This exercise-based recovery program will also assist clients in maintaining muscle mass and bone density to provide the physical foundation for recovery and to coincide with future medical advances. The Walk It Off program will not only benefit the recovery stages of a SCI but help with a client’s lifetime of physical well-being. People with SCIs not only face paralysis; there are also degenerative issues such as osteoporosis, circulatory and urinary tract diseases and physical regression that lead to a lower life expectancy. All of these require limb movement and weight bearing to slow the process and reduce the occurrences of these problems. Our facility will be the first of its kind in Ontario 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with others and also spread the word about Walk It Off Spinal Cord Recovery and Wellness.  There are many people with an SCI who don’t know about this option for recovery and rehabilitation.

THANK-YOU FOR YOUR TIME AND DONATION!!!!

MELISSA
story_txt:
FIRST:
Thank-you for taking the time to visit this page;  I am not an athlete...anyone who knows me knows this. Witnessing my cousin's positive attitude through his struggle and knowing how his life has changed, has inspired me to use my body in ways we don’t appreciate until they are gone.  
"I am only one, but still I am one. I cannot do everything, but still I can do something; and because I cannot do everything, I will not refuse to do something that I can do."
Helen Keller
Kevin's Story and the beginning of Walk It Off
This story is among one of the many that starts as a fun filled day and ends in tragedy. While celebrating a family wedding on the beach in Cuba, February 2009, my cousin Kevin Mills, age 28 at the time, was driven head first into the sand by a wave. Luckily, his new brother-in-law was able to pull him out of the water and to safety. Kevin broke his neck, sustaining a Spinal Cord Injury (SCI), was diagnosed a C4 ASIA A, quadriplegic and had no feeling or movement below the shoulders. Kevin and his wife Heather were both Advanced Care Paramedics in Toronto and now have experienced the medical system as both providers and patients. They have learned through our experiences that you must seek out and strive to provide the best care possible for your loved ones. They found that care at a SCI Recovery Centre in California, called Project Walk. They felt this specialized program should be available to our community and so began the process of building this unique not-for-profit SCI recovery centre, serving all of Ontario and beyond. 
**Note:  THE VIDEO ATTACHED SHOWS PEOPLE'S EXPERIENCES AND EXPLAINS WHY THE MONEY IS NEEDED FOR THE FES BIKE.  Please ignore the Aviva plea on the video.  Walk It Off unfortunately did not receive funding via Aviva and thus why I am doing this to help them still try and raise the much needed funds.

Walk it off is in desperate need of very expensive specialized equipment to assist with their recovery program.  
ALL funds raised through this campaign will go towards this equipment. Every little bit helps. Your funds will assist someone with a spinal cord injury to live their fullest quality of life and maybe even one day a possible recovery.

Traditionally, very little is asked of the paralyzed nervous system and muscles. This approach is known as the Dardzinski MethodTM of Spinal Cord Injury Recovery developed by Project Walk. This exercise-based recovery program will also assist clients in maintaining muscle mass and bone density to provide the physical foundation for recovery and to coincide with future medical advances. The Walk It Off program will not only benefit the recovery stages of a SCI but help with a client’s lifetime of physical well-being. People with SCIs not only face paralysis; there are also degenerative issues such as osteoporosis, circulatory and urinary tract diseases and physical regression that lead to a lower life expectancy. All of these require limb movement and weight bearing to slow the process and reduce the occurrences of these problems. Our facility will be the first of its kind in Ontario 
Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this campaign with others and also spread the word about Walk It Off Spinal Cord Recovery and Wellness.  There are many people with an SCI who don’t know about this option for recovery and rehabilitation.
THANK-YOU FOR YOUR TIME AND DONATION!!!!
MELISSA

story:
Help Fight Childhood Obesity!

We are a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization committed to fighting childhood obesity.  Body Sculpt has been helping New York school children for more than 20 years through a variety of programs and services and now we need your help to continue our mission.  This campaign will help fund our 10th Annual Children’s Sports & Fitness Expo.

The Expo is an annual FREE event where thousands of children have the opportunity to participate in over 25 sports activities, health screenings and nutrition clinics.  Through this event, families gain exposure to activities and services that will help them become physically fit thereby reducing the risk of obesity in their lives.  Some of these activities include: fencing, tennis, soccer, golf, archery, volleyball, capoeira, gymnastics, basketball, baseball and much more.  The sports clinics are conducted by over 35 Certified, Semi-Pro  collegiate athletes.

This year the 10th annual Children’s Sports & Fitness Expo will take place on Saturday, June 15, 2013 from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. at the Boys & Girls High School in Brooklyn, N.Y.

As President of Body Sculpt of New York and a personal trainer, my mission has always been to help people attain their fitness goals so they can live healthier lives.  The Expo has been the culmination of a dream for me.  We are changing lives, one family at a time and I hope you will see this as an opportunity to help make a difference in a child’s life.

 

How You Can Help

So, what are we going to do with your money?

As you can imagine, putting on an event this size is a HUGE undertaking.  The $10,000 we hope to raise will help us provide 25 sports activities and trainers to more than 5,000 children.  It will also help us to purchase t-shirts and provide breakfast and lunch for the 200 volunteers who are graciously donating their time from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Any funds raised above and beyond our goal of $10,000 will go towards offering a Six Weeks to Fitness program for parents and children immediately following the Expo.  You can find out more about our Six Weeks to Fitness program by going to www.sixweeks.com.

Can I count on you to help us meet or surpass our goal and make this the best Expo ever?

We at Body Sculpt of New York believe that if you introduce children to sports activities at a young age, they will find one that they enjoy and will continue into their adult years.  We are changing lives and generations.

As a not-for-profit, this means any donations you make are tax deductible and it also means that you are a wonderful person for caring enough to help.  To show you our gratitude, we’ve included a few perks which include (1) being listed on our website; (2) being listed in a souvenir program book; (3) t-shirts, (4) consultations with our fitness trainers, (5) consultations with our nutritionists (6) a customized meal plan.  Not only are you helping others, but you’re also helping yourself to stay fit and healthy.  Sounds like a win-win situation doesn’t it?  Even if you don’t need the fitness or nutrition services, you may wish to donate and pass on the perks to one of your family members or friends.

 

The Impact

We know you’ve all seen the alarming headlines about the childhood obesity epidemic.  The CDC reports that 18% of adolescents in America are obese and according to the New England Journal of Medicine children today will not live as long as their parents because of obesity.  To me, this is a call to action!

The Expo has a proven track record of being able to serve as an effective intervention that can contribute to behavior modification and increased awareness about the importance of proper nutrition and regular physical activity.  I hope you will help us continue this work. Visit http://www.bodysculpt.org for more information.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally get it if you can’t make a donation at this time, but there are other ways in which you can help.  You can start by spreading the word! Please tell your friends, co-workers, family, frenemies – anyone you can think of about our campaign.  Put it on blast through your social media networks.

Also, if you’re in the Brooklyn area on Saturday, June 15, 2013 from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., come out and visit us at the Expo.  We will be at Boys & Girls H.S., 1700 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11213.  With your help and support, we can continue to keep this wonderful event FREE for the community.

Thank you for your help, it’s greatly appreciated!

story:
This beautiful young lady is my God daughter Karissa. Karissa was diagnosed with a brain tumor when she was 10. She has had 5 surgeries and radiation to try to remove it. This particular tumor is reoccurring and surgeons have been unable to remove all of it because it is in the area of her pituitary gland and optic nerves.

     Karissa got married about 1 1/2 years ago to a great guy, Kevin. We all know life is tough enough when you are newly married without having medical complications. Last week we found out the tumor has grown and is causing problems. Karissa will undergo her 6th surgery on Oct 14.

     I am asking three things from those who read this:

First- Pray for Karissa for a successful surgery and a speedy recovery

Second- Share this post with your family and friends

Third- Give from your heart and lets exceed the goal

 

     Thank you all and God bless,

     Liz Crouch

story:
NoDoubt Workout Changes Lives Through Fitness!

NoDoubt Workout was started in 2004 by Cedric Duplessis Jr NASM/CPT/OPT/CES, to provide personal training sessions and group fitness classes in the New Orleans area.

The NoDoubt Workout group fitness classes are expanding rapidly. As of April 2013,  classes are being held at a new location and participant numbers are growing. NoDoubt Workout is raising funds to purchase aerobic step boards to accomodate the needs of the group fitness classes. 

Since Cedric started NoDoubt Workout, there are countless testimonials from clients explaining how his intense motivation and extensive knowledge base has helped to change their lives through successful weight loss. Cedric is passionate about fitness and his clients. Every person that he trains knows how important they are to him because of how he is able to motivate them to achieve their fitness goals, no matter what. Whether you are attending a group fitness class or a personal training session, Cedric makes sure that you will push yourself to get a good workout, NoDoubt!

One of the essential pieces to the group fitness classes is the aerobic step boards. It is imperative that NoDoubt gain the capacity to purchase approximately 30 step boards so that all participants in the NoDoubt group fitness classes have access to the intense workout Cedric offers.

Let's Be Specific...

NoDoubt Workout needs to purchase approximately 30 step boards for group fitness classes. The step boards cost $100 each (not including taxes and shipping), thus a need to raise $3000 to cover the costs of the boards.

If you are able to donate, NoDoubt Workout is offering great perks that include free group fitness classes, NoDoubt Workout T-Shirts, NoDoubt Workout DVD's, and Individual Fitness Profiles.

Whether the fundraising goal is met or not, NoDoubt Workout will use the funds to purchase as many aerobic step boards as the donated funds will allow.

Other Ways You Can Help...

For those of you who are interested in helping NoDoubt Workout expand but are unable to donate, we ask that you spread the word about our fitness classes and our funding campaigns.

We would be happy to see you bring a friend to class and use the Indiegogo share tool!

Contact Me

To learn more about NoDoubt Workout, contact Cedric via email at cedric@nodoubtworkout.com or via cell at 504.258.4748.

story:
My name's Ben, I'm a 22 year old college student in Fredericksburg, VA. I plan on majoring in English and hopefully will have a career in GSM rights and activism. Being that I'm a college student, extra money isn't really something that's a common occurence in my life and help is always appreciated when I can get it. While I've only just recently come out as trans*, my chest has always been a major source of dysphoria for me and to be able see my body reflect how I feel internally would be a major positive effect in my life and my overall mental health. 

The standard procedure is around $6,000, not including extra fees and and unexpected expenses. This is (understandably) a rather large expense, and to be able to raise even a quarter of that would be a huge success.

story:
Custom-made necklaces inspired by people's data

Buzz about this project: Huffington Post, BBC, The Observer, Wall Street Journal, Wired, The Guardian, Domestic Sluttery.

I'm Stef, a designer and software developer from London and I'm seeking your help in creating and launching the Data Necklace - a set of bespoke, laser-cut necklaces individually made for someone that displays their data in a beautiful way.

Tweets, dates, meaningul words can all be visualised in a unique way to reflect the wearer's personality, history or stories.

A Necklace that visualises how often you use the word "love" on Twitter? (Or a word of your choice...)

The "love" necklace displays an entire year of tweets by a person. The lengths of the beads indicate the number of tweets in a month. The shorter lengths indicate how often she used the word "love" that month. I can do the same for any word.

Along the sides of every other bead you'll see a single laser-etched tweet for that period. They're visible if you hold up the beads to the light, and are partially public, partially private. I like to think of them as little reminders, memories, almost like a 21st Century locket.

 

The design is totally personal - I download the person's tweets, run them through some software that I've writetn, and based on a particular word ("happy", "want", "amazing") the result is a laser-cut and laser-etched necklace, hand-assembled with a sterling silver chain. I had to learn how to make jewellery in the process!

This product is just past the "prototype" stage and I'm refining the design for a limited run. You'd be helping me do that.

What I need to make this happen

The prototypes you can see on the Data Necklace gallery are all made using a laser-cutter, from a variety of materials. It's expensive experimenting with a laser-cutter! The hourly rate just to be in the room is £50. Then there are the materials - silver is also expensive. So I'm looking for funds to help me experiment and perfect the designs that I'm developing. 

If we reach my funding goal then I'd have enough funds to experiment and perfect the following additional designs and begin making them.

If I exceed the goal I could even buy a laser cutter, invest in marketing and design around the product and improve my chances of making this project a success.

The other designs

In addition to the Twitter Necklace I have two other designs that I'm developing.

The Felt Data Necklace

 

 
Inspired by the wool-making and design traditions of the Inner Hebrides, Scotland, this is a visualisation of a person's Twitter activity over the period of a year, rendered as a felt "collar" necklace. 73 ellipses, representing 5-day periods of a year are cut from a single piece of coloured felt.

The resulting necklace can be hung in a box frame for presentation. I'm experimenting with this piece, because I am yet to perfect how to ensure that the felt does not snap, as one of the prototypes has done already. 

The Text Necklace

A series of pairs of words and numeric values that are rendered as a necklace.

A set of beads matches the values (the larger the number, the longer and more bulbous the bead), and along each bead the text you've supplied is laser-etched.

The results are quite stunning. However, this is the most experimental - I need to develop and perfect the way that people supply the data, and also how I communicate with them about the potential design before it is cut, so that they are happy with it. 

Why I need your support

Something that people will cherish

What's lovely about this project for me personally, is that it was a product of a Hack Day, a show at the Whitechapel Gallery and my experience on an amazing Scottish Island. Read more about the Story.

A tiny idea that I had that I wanted to make for friends and family, that lets me do something using my existing skills of software and design, but results in something that they can hold in their hands, that doesn't evaporate like all the websites I made between 1996 and 2006!

I want to make something that people will really care about and cherish.

Judging by the smiles so far, I think I'm onto something!

 

With your support, I'll be taking what is a prototype and turning it into a product that people can buy.

I'm able to produce a great first product straight away, the Twitter Necklace, but my ambition is to make this the first of a number of designs that I would eventually offer.

That's what you would be supporting in the long run.

Using a wide range of different types of data I hope to be able to produce very personal, data-driven designs that mean something to the wearer.

The You're All Awesome Necklace

 

As a thank you to all of the supporters for this project, we're making a "You're All Awesome" necklace, that incorporates the Twitter usernames and/or some tweets that visualises the collective use of the word "awesome" in your timelines. Because you all are!

Other Ways You Can Help

There's a Facebook page. You could "like" it and invite your friends to do the same.

Spread the Word by tweeting or blogging about this idea.

Give me feedback about how to make this happen.

I'm excited. I hope you'll help me do this thing, and I'm really grateful to everyone who is helping me achieve this.

Thank you!

There's a Facebook page. You could "like" it and invite your friends to do the same.
Spread the Word by tweeting or blogging about this idea.
Give me feedback about how to make this happen.
I'm excited. I hope you'll help me do this thing, and I'm really grateful to everyone who is helping me achieve this.

Thank you!

story:
The Project

Act like a pro.

The only real affective way to get "prevented
maintenance" and keeping your weapon  and yourself  in fully readiness condition 24/7

The "GSC  - Gun Shot Counter™


is a revolutionary new system that enables the real time recording and storing
of gunfire data. The GSC is fitted with revolutionary software that is able to automatically collect and store gunfire data making it available for off-line analysis of both user and weapon.

Now, with the GSC you can know the exact condition of your gun, and your personal performance! The GSC is equipped with Real Time Clock, meaning that each round is stamped with date and time so now you can know immediately how fast you shot! so you have a great tool to improve your skills,

The GSC even records the ammo energy level...

 and much more:

  • Increases weapon's readiness, reliability & safety.

  •  Improves shooting skills: Act like a pro. Each round is stored with date & time: Now you can know how fast you shot-spilts 

  •  Accumulated data can be easily downloaded to a PC or Android device (with USB host capability) throught Micro USB cable connection for off-line analysis of user & weapon.

  •  Counts every shot for better maintenance.

  •  Standard replaceable battery for many years of operation.

  • Records energy level.

  • Share the information with your friends.

The downloaded data is saved on the user's PC or Android device and can be easily deleted by the users.


 

We do hope to finish the iOS App soon.

 Android APP,with the exact time and splits

 Symbols for fast or very fast shooting:

 

Picatinny GSC unit

Picatinny GSC unit-Red 

Glock GSC unit

 This is how we think the box should look like

 

Some more information
Secubit-Ltd  was founded about 4 years ago by two friends.

 We first invested our own money trying to develop the basic concept and prototype. After we realized that it's a bit (…) more complicated product and additional funds are needed, we raised the additional funds from friends and "angles" and got some serious professionals assistance in order to develop the product. 

On October 2013 we got  US patent: # 8,571,815

Eventually we have completed the development of two different units (for Glock-19,17,18 Gen 3 and a univeral picatinny rail mount ) that have been tested and approved by few security forces around the world (they are really excited with our product) and by a certified lab, but our main goal is to have the GSC on the commercial market and that's exactly where we need your support.

This is me about 4 years ago testing the first prototype

And a video from the begining (4 years ago)




Indiegogo campaign

Here’s where you come in.

We're now raising $25,000, which will allow us to produce the GSC units in a large scale (purchase the components and assemble the units) . In return for your early and much appreciated support, you'll be one the first to get the GSC, get some pretty great perks, and support a company trying to redefine and improve the way people use, train and take care of their guns.
If we won't raise our goal, we will simply manufacture fewer units in order to be able to send them to you, our contributors.

 

 

 

For 5 $ Formal "Thank you letter"  from Secubit. 

We really appreciate your support 

For 84$ - One "GSC" unit (Glock or Picatinny mount) including PC software and Android APP. Free worldwide shipping.

For 161$ - Two "GSC units" (Glock or Picatinny mount) including PC software and Android APP.Free worldwide shipping.

For 225$ – Three "GSC" units (Glock or Picatinny mount) including PC software and Android APP. Free worldwide shipping.

For 292$ - Four "GSC" units (Glock or Picatiny mount)  including PC software and Android APP). Free worldwide shipping.

story:
**updates**

  • Nov 25th: Concept drawings for the park will be posted next week! Your making this happen.
  • Nov 5th: Thanks for all the donations so far people! It's already making a difference.
  • Oct 17th: Site Meeting with Etafeni & Cape Town Council. Park name to be "ZWELITSHA"!
  • Oct 16th: Contract Signed! The City of Cape Town has recently given Etafeni and myself the go ahead to get working on the land. YES MANN! We can start!
  • Oct 11th: Preliminary meeting at Etafeni with Parks Department Cape Town Municipality, Nyange Councilor and Stephanie Kilroe (Etafeni Trustee)

Public Park in a Township

I am a self employed Landscape Architect trying to do more work for townships (AKA squatter camps) around South Africa. I have been educated in the U.S and Norway, starting my degree at California Polytechnic University in San Luis Obispo and completing my masters at the University of Life Sciences in Norway.

My recent thesis on alternatives to low cost housing for informal settlements sparked my enthusiasm in helping township and squatter camp communities. I want to put more of my time and energy into creating parks and recreational spaces for our people living below the poverty line.

Townships are some of the most densely populated human settlements, many of which have little to no open space for the community to enjoy. During Apartheid these tracts of land were given very little services and zero to very little town planning. Facilities such as toilets, roads, sidewalks or recreational open space (parks) were never even considered. 

Many of these townships today are so densely populated today (5 x more than New York City!) that kids are forced to recreate along the sides of freeways!

The need for open space is dire!



It's hard for me to see people still living in such conditions. I consider myself fortunate for where I grew up and the ability to go to school in a safe environment. I therefore want to offer the skills I gained from University and help these underprivileged communities and townships. 


The Project

I've managed to team up with an inspirational Non-profit organization called Etafeni (www.etafeni.org) which is based in a township called Nyanga, located on the outskirts of Cape Town. 

After meeting with Etafeni's Development Manager, Stephanie Kilroe, and other members from Cape Town Municipality and Nyanga, we have set our aim at developing a park that focuses on uplifting the community and more specifically, the youth! 

Typical of many townships, Nyanga is a densely populated area. It has very little open space and very few parks for the residents to recreate in and enjoy. Many of the kids are  then forced to recreate in the roads or along sidewalks!



As of October 16th 2013, The City of Cape Town has recently given Etafeni and myself the go ahead to get working on the land. YES MANN! Our first major step!

I have offered to volunteer what I can afford on this project, but what I am hoping for here is funding that allows us to build a park that no township has seen before! We want this park to be the best it can be. We want to give these kids a park they can feel safe in and enjoy! The more help we get, the better the park will be and the better life the kids will have. This may sound far fetched but a better community, helps makes a better town, a better country and finally a better world. A better quality of life for all of us!

We envision this park becoming one of the many gems within Nyanga, having a positive knock on effect that 

  • uplifts the youth through education and awareness
  • deters the youth from drugs and alcohol through recreation
  • creates localized employment
  • uplifts the community and value of the area.
  • sets a precedent for future community driven initiatives

The Project will need over $50, 000 in order to reach our goals!

The project will use local materials and labour. Local residents will be the people building the park. They will acquire building skills that will help them gain jobs in the market place. The maintenance crew will also be sourced locally. The idea is to keep the jobs and employment localized, thus uplifting the area!

In order to make this project work we are relying on funding, skilled personal and materials. The administering of the project alone will need an estimated $4,000 (R40, 000) (NOK 25, 000) (€3,000)


  • Anything you donate will make a difference and I can assure you it will help those in need. Our aim is to get the kids off the street and into a safe area. The more funding we get the more better the park will be. 

Design Criteria

  • One of our dreams is to have a basketball court: We (Myself, Etafeni, the Nyanga community) want to keep the youth active, positive, off the streets and drugs and alcohol.
  • Use of indigenous plants: We want the park to be local! Indigenous fauna = water wise / sustainable. We want to label and describe each plant / herb / vegetable thus educating the public. Think hip botanical garden!
  • Seating and board games that appeal to both the youth and adults. We want the park to cater to both young and old! 
  • Food Garden: Many of the residents here are HIV positive and under nourished. By mimicking Etafeni's already established Nutritional Program (http://www.etafeni.org/programmes.php) , our aim is to feed and educate the community.
  • Employ full-time care takers making this park a safe haven for kids anytime of day. We want the kids to have a safe outdoor recreational area they can enjoy worry free. This also means the parents are worry free!



The Impact of Your Donation

Your help will go a long way. Simply; it will help hundreds of people. The knocked on of a positive gesture is unbounding. By donating you are contributing to the upgrading and upliftment of one of the most impoverished communities in the world. This is a place that needs your positive gesture.

Majority of the residents in Nyanga are well below the poverty line and live in one of the most violent townships in Cape Town. Please help contribute and make Nyanga a safe place one can be proud of.

You can donate from anywhere in the world by using this website's facility. It's safe and trustworthy. However if you are within South Africa / Norway and would prefer to do a wire or internet transfer, please e-mail me for the account details.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate funds but perhaps have a skill or equipment you can offer please let us know. As far as skills go we are looking for an engineer, photographer/videographer and webpage designer/administrator.   

I would just like to thank everyone for taking the time to read this. I find it's most often through unity and collaboration that we can solve much of our problems today. Facing a problem alone can be daunting but together it is possible.

Please could you share this campaign and thanks for being apart of this.

For more info about me, reference letters and previous work please see www.UniteAndCo.com/who.html

Regards

Andrew Blair

info@UniteAndCo.com

Contact Details

Project Contacts : Please feel free to contact anyone of these people regarding the project:

  • Etafeni : Non-Profit Organization www.etafeni.org                                           Sihume Road, Nyanga, Cape Town 7750. Tel +27 21 386 1516
  • Stephanie Kilroe : Etafeni Development Manager: stephanie@intermail.co.za
  • Enrico January : City Parks, City of Cape Town Municipality Tel +27 21 630 1744 enrico.january@capetown.gov.za

Personal References:

  • Wichada Treepoonpon. SWECO. Landscape Architecture. +4798008936 , wit@sweco.no
  • Ted Gosstyla. ted@gosstyla.com
  • Jonatan Svartas. Tegn3:  Architecture / Urban Design / Landscape Architecture  +47 92267232 , jonatan.svartas@tegn3.no
  • Duane Conover. dconover1@socal.rr.com

story:
In Short....

My name is Cashmere Nicole. Yes, my boobs were broken. Not only were my boobs broken. My entire world came crashing down after learning of my breast cancer diagnosis. After hearing of my diagnosis, the thoughts that went through my mind were: HOW? WHY ME? OMG...OMG...THIS is HUGE. My daughter, my company and everything that I had spent 26 years building was threatened. I thought about planning my own funeral and I even thought about how I'd like my daughter to be raised.

I'm thankful to be here today; alive and well enough to fight back. Just before I was diagnosed, I had begun building my company 'Beauty Bakerie Cosmetics Brand'. It had been my lifelong dream to begin my own company. However, upon my illness all operations were forced to a screeching halt. Marketing stopped. Sales stopped. Everything had to be stopped.

I find a hard time still accepting that a classmate of mine named, Kelly Brooke Anderson passed away from breast cancer the morning I awoke from reconstruction surgery. I reached out to her mother because I felt as though Kelly passed her torch to me. If she were alive, she'd continue trying to make strides in raising awareness.

I understand fully now why I had to endure this tragedy...recreating my brand by merging my passion with my testimony to save lives.

What I need and What You Get...

I hope to raise 25,000. I will use these funds to recreate and rebrand my company: website, repackaging, design, distribution). This also includes promotional and marketing objectives that will include bringing awareness to young women all over through visiting colleges and organizations. I'd like to give makeovers to breast cancer patients to inspire them to continue the fight. Lastly, it's my hope to have a song written along with a music video that will shed light on my experience and the love story that evolved from tragedy.

I have some pretty neat perks based on your level of donation or participation with my campaign, including the opportunity to meet me in person and assist me in making over a patient! If I do not reach my entire goal, I will use whatever funds I have obtained and continue to fight to make this happen!

We all know someone who believes that cancer cannot happen to them because they are young, because they are busy living their dreams or because it just can't. They need a face behind this.. I just want to speak to them using whatever avenues and platforms I have: family, friends, campaigns, companies, music, etc. 

If you cannot donate, please use the Indiegogo Share tools and share this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter or Instagram, especially now that they have video;)

Again, thank you SOOOOOOO much for your support as I carry the torch that was passed on to me from Kelly!

Cashmere Nicole

story:
Hi everyone!

A few summers ago I worked as a camp counselor and was fortunate to have a beautiful camper, Alexa, in my group. Alexa was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes 3 years ago. Type 1 diabetes is a lifelong chronic disease in which there are high levels of sugar in the blood. Alexa wears an insulin pump all the time to help keep her going. 

Alexa's message:

 "Hi :) My name is Alexa Akmal I'm 14 years old and I have Type 1 Diabetes. I have had Diabetes for 3 years now and it is one of the hardest things I've ever had to deal with. But in the end it has made me the person I am today. I am thankful to have friends and family that support me 100 percent of the time. I wear an insulin pump all of the time to keep myself alive. I also attend Diabetes camp every year. It has shown me that I'm not alone and that other teenagers my age struggle to fit in everyday because of this. It gives me a better outlook on life and that I'm not being punished with Diabetes.  So many other young people are effected by this disease. It puts a strain on school work, family, and friendships. This year I am walking in the 2011 JDRF Walk to Cure Diabetes. Please donate to this wonderful cause so that we find a cure and I am no longer battling Diabetes. Thank you.
Love Alexa"


On Sunday, October 23rd there will be a walk for JDRF Walk to Cure Diabetes held at the College of Staten Island. I, along with the girls of Alpha Theta Upsilon, ask that you donate to Alexa's team, Alexa's Angels, so we can help find a cure for diabetes. Everyone is welcome to walk with us. Any amount helps!


Thank you!
